* Summary of the invention
* Provides an apparatus and method for continuously conducting an anodic oxidation and electrolytic coloring of an aluminum strip or wire without need for a large amount of electrical energy

* Objects of the invention include providing an apparatus and method for continuously conducting first an anodic oxidation and then an electrolytic coloring of an aluminum strip or wire for forming a colored anodic coating on the aluminum strip or wire, this film or layer having excellent weatherability or fade resistance

* The invention relates to an apparatus of continuous electrolytic coloring of an aluminum strip or wire comprising a means for continuously supplying an aluminum strip or wire, an anodic oxidation bath for anodizing the aluminum strip or wire and having a cathode disposed therein, an electrolytic coloring bath for electrolytically coloring the anodized aluminum strip or wire, this electrolytic coloring bath containing at least one of a nickel salt, a cobalt salt, a copper salt, a tin salt, and selenious acid and having an anode disposed therein, an electric circuit for connecting the cathode and the anode to a power source and causing the aluminum strip or wire to function as an anode in the anodic oxidation bath and to function as a cathode in the electrolytic coloring bath without connecting the aluminum strip or wire directly to a power source, and a means for passing the aluminum strip or wire continuously and successively through the baths

* The anodic oxidation bath composition used in the invention is usually an aqueous solution of 10 to 55% sulfuric acid, but if desired, the bath may further contain a small amount of a salt such as magnesium chloride, sodium sulfate, magnesium sulfate, sodium chloride, etc.; a carboxylic acid; an organic sulfonic acid; and/or an amine
* The electric current used in the anodic oxidation can be a direct current or direct and alternating superposed currents and in",0

247,"  <summary>
* Swash plate type compressor

column2: + Illustrated in FIG. 1 is a perspective and exploded view of an automotive swash plate type compressor
+ Comprises a two-piece cylinder block, reciprocating pistons, and a swash plate
+ Swash plate rotates about a shaft, and pistons reciprocate within cylinder bores
+ Facial surfaces of the swash plate contact pivoting shoes, and end surface may contact pistons
+ Coating on the swash plate reduces frictional wear on components
+ Made from non-hypereutectic aluminum or aluminum alloys containing less than 10% silicon
+ Coating comprises polyfluoro elastomer, lubricious additive, and load bearing additive
+ Applied by means of liquid spray, and ratio of liquid to solid portions is between 40% to 90% liquid portion to 60% to 10% solid portion
+ Preferred is a ratio of 70% liquid portion to 30% solid portion
+ Swash plate is usually manufactured by a forging process and requires machining steps before final production tolerance
+ Roughened surface textures are formed on surfaces by abrasive grit blasting, electro-discharge machining, honing, or rough machining
+ Photomicrographs showing a cross-sectional view of coated swash plates are reproduced in FIGS. 2 and 3

259,"  <summary>
* Fabric treatment apparatus

column2: + Invention relates to an apparatus for treating a dyed or printed textile web with a liquid
+ Object of the invention is to provide an improved apparatus for treating a textile web with a liquid
+ Apparatus includes a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch
+ Conveyor includes an endless sieve belt for transporting the textile web along a predetermined path
+ Liquid applicator applies the liquid to the web during motion along the path
+ Suction device removes the liquid from the web by suction during motion of the web along the path
+ Dwell stretch conducts the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop
+ Invention is especially advantageous for treating knitted fabrics
+ Can have a compact construction
+ Suction device causes the textile web to adhere to the belt and to be entrained thereby
+ Drum and rollers enable the textile web to be guided with little tension

column1: </summary>

264,"  • The present invention relates to frame quilting machines used to sew patterns into large textiles, particularly bedspreads and quilts.

• The invention includes a method of duplicating a selected pattern over an entire bedspread or quilt, and a system wherein the sewing machine function is controlled by one computer, while the quilting table motion is controlled by a separate computer.

• The invention also relates to a reprogrammable function integrated into the system, where the operator draws the desired pattern on a monitor using a mouse, and the tracing function is facilitated through a computer-aided design program.

• The present invention can also be defined as an apparatus for sewing thread into fabric, comprising a first structure supporting a sewing machine head, a second structure supporting the fabric, and the second structure capable of horizontal movement in the X-direction, Y-direction, or any combination.",0

* *Summary of the Invention* *

1. The invention relates to a flexible traction element which can be wound and unwound, particularly for passenger and/or goods lifts, consisting of at least one stranded cable made of a material guaranteeing tensile strength.

2. The production line for embedding at least one stranded cable in a flexible thermoplastic material includes a reel for unwinding the stranded cables, a device for precisely orienting the stranded cables, a heater for preheating the stranded cables, and a cooling trough.

3. The method for producing a traction element according to the invention includes degreasing and/or pretreating the stranded cables, preheating the liquefied plastics material to a temperature of about ±20° C. of the melting temperature, and sheathing the stranded cables with the liquefied plastics material in an extruder.
4. The stranded cables are tensioned with a tensile force of 5 to 100 N, and the outlet opening of the extruder determines the geometrical cross-sectional shape of the traction elements.
5. The traction elements have a wide range of use, including lifting and pulling of loads, and can be used as electric conductors.
</summary>

column2: 1. The present invention relates to materials and methods for producing silicon-based micro and nanofibers.
2. The invention involves the use of liquid silanes, polymers, accelerants, and solvents to produce silicon-based nanowires and composites.
3. The invention provides a viable method for utilizing liquid cyclosilanes and linear or branched silanes in the fabrication of electronic materials.

column1: 271,"  <summary>
* Summary of the Invention

column2: + * Object of the Present Invention

column3: + * Providing an arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel

column4: - * Including a plurality of controllers, each coupled to a different spool holder
- * Each controller having a brake rotor and an adjustable, tension responsive braking element
- * The arrangement also includes a tensioning lever coupled to the braking element for biasing it
- * The tensioning lever has a roller adapted to engage and be biased by the threads
- * The biasing arrangement is operable to influence the tensioning lever and is simultaneously settable by fluid pressure
- * The force generated by the biasing arrangement operates in addition to the weight force on the tensioning lever, allowing the thread tension to be altered
- * The biasing arrangement can be a piston/cylinder assembly, which can readily follow the swinging movement of the tensioning lever by changing their length

- * The piston/cylinder arrangement can also operate on a brake shoe, which is provided to a further rotating braking surface, allowing the braking to occur rapidly at the shut down of the warping machine

column2: + * Description of Related Art

column3: + * The creel arrangements presently on the marketplace have the advantage that the force exercised by the braking band automatically decreases as the wind diameter of each spool is reduced
+ * The weight distribution on the tensioning lever is predetermined and thus also the thread tension exercised by the creel spools on the threads

+ * From DE OS 19 18 161, it is known to provide electromagnetic brakes to all spool holders to drive all magnets in parallel switching and to alter the activation current by a common setting arrangement

+ * From DE PS 88 3 727, it is known to provide pneumatic biasing arrangements to thread brakes in which the biasing for a plurality of thread brakes in a spool creel can be centrally set and controlled

277,"  <summary>
* *Bedroom Cabinet*
* *Summary of the Invention*

It is an object of the present invention to provide a bedroom cabinet in which the external surfaces are formed to be flat, and wherein a plurality of cabinets can be stacked or installed adjacent to each other without any obstruction.

The present invention provides a bedroom cabinet formed into a box-shape by a hexahedron consisting of four side surfaces, an upper surface and a lower surface, and comprising an outer casing and an inner casing. The outer casing is composed of an upper and lower outer casings, and the inner casing is positioned within the outer casing. The bedroom cabinet of the present invention is of the dual construction, and therefore it is excellent in mechanical strength.
</summary>
<level 2>
* *Description of the Preferred Embodiments*

One embodiment of a bedroom cabinet of the present invention shown in FIGS. 1 through 6 will be described. The upper and lower outer housings are internally provided with an inner casing comprising a front panel, a back panel, left and right side panels, a ceiling panel, and a bottom panel. The upper surface portion and back surface portion of the upper outer housing and the lower surface portion of the lower outer housing are respectively formed with a plurality of recesses having a required width. The peripheral edge at the lower end of the upper outer housing and the peripheral edge at the upper end of the lower outer housing are respectively formed with horizontally outwardly projecting flanges.
</level 2>

292,"  <summary>
• The present invention relates to systems and methods for producing or delivering heat at or near the down hole end of production tubing of a producing oil or gas well.

• The invention addresses two primary shortcomings of conventional down hole heating systems: (1) the heat is not properly focused where it needs to be, and (2) existing systems fail due to design elements that are not resistant to chemical or physical attack.

• The present invention provides a down hole heating system that includes electrical resistance type heater rods, heat insulating packer, perforated tubing, stainless steel collars, and a heating unit with suitably shielded electrical connections. The system focuses heat in the production zone to promote flow to, and not just within, the production tubing. Additionally, the use of stainless steel collars and cement block helps to protect the electrical connections from attack.
</summary>",0
293,"  <summary>
* *Summary of the Invention* *

* *1. Provide down hole service equipment, such as wire line controlled pulling tools, that will effectively take the form of an external pull tool or overshot for use in well servicing operations or an internal pull tool or spear, depending on the particular service operation involved.*

* *2. The invention is adapted to be provided on a wire line controlled pulling tool and run into the well casing or well bore for the purpose of establishing a mechanical connection with an object positioned in the well bore and applying sufficient force thereto to remove the object from the well.*

* *3. The pulling tool takes the form of an external overshot or an internal spear, in each case, the tool structure taking the form of an outer tubular body having an inner body structure disposed in movable relation therein.*

* *4. Telescoping movement of the inner and outer body structures of the tool causes the overshot or spear to selectively move into gripping relationship with the object that is to be removed from the well bore.*

* *5. The tubular outer body is secured about the inner body by means of a catch mechanism having a locking position and an unlocking position, depending upon the relative positions of the inner and outer body structures.*

* *6. A pin structure forming a part of the catch mechanism is selectively positioned within pin receiving grooves and a control spring is employed to ensure that the pin alternately enters one or the other of a pair of unlocking or locking grooves each time the inner and outer body structures are cycled linearly relative to one another.*

* *7. If the pulling tool is locked in relation to the down hole object, unlocking may be achieved simply by downward movement of the control line tool followed by subsequent upward movement thereof.*

* *8. Further, in the event the pulling tool is unlocked with respect to the down hole object, locking may be achieved simply by downward movement of the pulling tool, followed by subsequent upward movement thereof.*
* *9. The invention provides a simple and efficient mechanism for installing and removing objects in wells, including objects that may be stuck or lost within a well bore.*
</summary>",0

column1: 298,"  <summary>
* Position sensors used to monitor moving objects generate an electrical signal that is proportional to the distance between the moving object and a fixed position.

* Most position sensing transducers also generate low frequency noise in the form of a slowly drifting or static DC offset, or error signals that may be a significant portion of the total overall signal.
* The present invention is directed to sensing position or movement of an object.

* One embodiment of the invention is herein described as a sensor that may comprise a waveform generator and an error correction generator for modifying a sensing signal by removing unneeded power and providing the signal to a remote monitor via two wires useful in multiplexing multiple sensors.

* The error correction generator determines and eliminates strong static signals and error signals that do not deliver information about a position of an object being sensed, wherein inclusion of the static and error signals would require energy.

* One embodiment may include a digitally stored offset and error correction closed-loop compensation circuit for constantly comparing a value of the conditioned sensing signal to a desired minimum value and generates a correction signal that is subtracted from the offset and error signal to deliver a sensor signal output that is close to a desired minimum value.

* The constant comparing of the sensor signal output to the desired minimum value proceeds in a first direction relative to a direction of sensor output signals generated when an object being sensed moves in a relatively slow manner compared to a nominal speed of objects being monitored such that signals are generated as the objects move are not subtracted from the sensor output to a degree significant enough to cause significant variance between a position of the object and a signal level delivered by the sensor indicating the position.

* Further, the constant comparing of the sensor signal output to the desired minimum proceeds in a second direction relative to the direction of signals generated when the object being monitored moves in a relatively fast manner compared to the speed of objects being monitored so signals generated by errors or from other noise sources are subtracted from the sensor output in a manner sufficient to allow for a deletion of these error or static signals from being a significant portion of the position signal generated by the sensor.

* One embodiment of the invention may include a window reference circuit that constantly compares a desired conditioned sensor signal output to an existing conditioned sensor signal output and adjusts the conditioned sensor signal output if it is",0

301,"  <summary>
* *Brief Summary of the Invention* *
* *Key Points* *
tab * *Inserted Separating Walls* *
1. The present invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for a fluid machine, particularly a gas turbine.
2. The invention avoids the disadvantages of the prior art by using separate inserts instead of casting the separating walls together with the apparatus.
tab * *Advantages of the Invention* *
1. No large amount of material in the transitional region between the hot-gas wall and the insert.
2. No thermal stresses between the insert and the hot-gas wall.
tab * *Description of the Preferred Embodiment* *
1. The flow deflection apparatus is in the form of a hollow casting.
2. Holders, which are in the form of rails and into which the separating walls are inserted, are integrally formed in the interior of the flow deflection apparatus.
tab * *Conclusion* *

The invention provides a simple and efficient solution for cooling flow deflection apparatuses, particularly in the context of gas turbines. The use of inserts instead of casting the separating walls together with the apparatus leads to several advantages, including reduced material consumption and improved thermal performance.",0
302,"  <summary>
• The present invention relates to a system and method for controlling the operation of a fuel delivery system for a vehicle, such as a throttle valve.
• The system comprises a control unit that receives a signal indicating accelerator pedal position and a signal indicating the position of the throttle valve.
• The control unit processes the signals to provide a control signal to a DC motor that automatically sets the throttle position for optimal performance of the vehicle.
• The control unit also provides an output signal that controls a clutch, which connects the accelerator pedal directly to the throttle valve when manual control is desired.
• During manual control, the vehicle driver has full control of the vehicle.
• Changing control from automatic to manual does not occur until the throttle valve is moved to a predetermined position or is positioned to match what is commanded by the accelerator pedal.
• This prevents the vehicle from lurching forward or stalling when control is shifted from automatic to manual.
</summary>",0

• Technical function of the embodiments described above includes that the female link receives the male link to allow translation of the male link relative to the female link and to form a radial interface, wherein the radial interface dampens translation of the male link relative to the female link, and a pin releasably couples the male link and the female link to selectively retain the male link and the female link.
• Other aspects, features, and techniques of the embodiments will become more apparent from the following description taken in conjunction with the drawings.

• The female link receives the male link to allow translation of the male link relative to the female link and to form a radial interface, wherein the radial interface dampens translation of the male link relative to the female link.
• The pin releasably couples the male link and the female link to selectively retain the male link and the female link.
• The pin can serve as a fusible link and shear when a sufficiently strong shock or heavy load is applied.
• The pin is designed to shear at a known load magnitude corresponding to the maximum structural capability of the gearbox assembly, the unfused mount components, and the engine mounting structure.
• The pin must be at least strong enough to withstand peak non-destructive impact loads such as low cycle loads from hard landings and other non-routine but expected shocks.
• The pin will not break until loads at least 10-25 times higher than expected low cycle loads are experienced.
• Very few loads experienced during aircraft engine operation reach these levels, but shocks due to blade-off events can be high enough to shear the pin.
</summary>",0

314,"  <summary>
* * Summary of the Invention

column2: + * The present invention relates to turbines and methods for minimizing flow disturbance during periodic operational testing of inlet control valves.
+ * The invention uses control valve positions as feedback to compensate for flow changes during testing.

+ * The flow is determined as a function of control valve position, and the difference in flow between the open and closed valve conditions is used to calculate the flow demand for the remaining valves.
+ * The invention also includes a test compensation circuit that uses the flow demand from the non-tested valves to calculate the flow compensation required for the tested valve.

column1: </summary>
<level2>
* * Brief Description of the Invention

column2: + * The present invention is a method of using control valve position as feedback into a compensation function to minimize flow disturbance caused by the closing and reopening of a turbine control valve during periodic operational testing.
+ * The method uses the total mass flow through several parallel turbine inlet flow control valves as a function of control valve position to calculate the flow demand for the remaining valves.
+ * The flow compensation required for the tested valve is calculated using the flow demand from the non-tested valves.

318,"  <summary>
* Kinematic mounts are used in precision optical instruments and other high-performance machinery.

* The mounts must fulfill two major requirements: 1) it must not adversely affect the stability of the instrument through the attachment to a less precise spacecraft structure, and 2) it must provide a strong and stable support system to the instrument during launch and minimize the loads transmitted to the mounted instrument.
* The inventions provide a damped kinematic mount that incorporates novel damping features to protect the instrument from potentially damaging flight loads.
* The mounts are designed to provide the desired performance characteristics by arranging the instrument support means with first and second damping means.
* The damping means and instrument support means are arranged to provide the desired performance characteristics.
* The inventions provide a passive energy dissipating mechanism to protect the instrument from potentially damaging flight loads.
* The kinematic mounts have been modified by inserting vibration damping materials into the mounts.
* The damping mechanism may be provided at machined hinge or flexure locations of the mounts.
* The damping materials introduce a damping mechanism into the six mount suspension modes, thus dissipating into heat and reducing the high energy disturbances to the instrument.
</summary>

320,"  <summary>
* * Summary of the Invention

* The present invention relates to a combustion engine with multiple cylinders and a water injection system to improve efficiency and reduce emissions. The engine includes a combustion cylinder, an expansion cylinder, and a water injection system that injects water into the exhaust gas flowing into the expansion cylinder. The water injection system is designed to improve the thermal efficiency of the engine by reducing the temperature of the exhaust gas and increasing the amount of energy that can be recovered from the exhaust gas.
* Sub-Summary
* * Features of the Invention

* The combustion engine includes multiple cylinders, with each cylinder having a combustion chamber and an exhaust port. The water injection system is located in the exhaust port and injects water into the exhaust gas flowing into the expansion cylinder. The water injection system is designed to improve the thermal efficiency of the engine by reducing the temperature of the exhaust gas and increasing the amount of energy that can be recovered from the exhaust gas.
* * Advantages of the Invention

* The water injection system improves the thermal efficiency of the engine by reducing the temperature of the exhaust gas and increasing the amount of energy that can be recovered from the exhaust gas. This results in a reduction in emissions and an improvement in fuel efficiency. Additionally, the water injection system can be used in combination with other emissions reduction technologies, such as catalytic converters, to further improve the efficiency and reduce the emissions of the engine.",0

327,"  • The present invention relates to a system for assessing segmentations from various sources.
• The invention provides an apparatus for automatically assessing radiation therapy segmentations.

• The electronic computer receives a first and second electronic file each providing data points describing different three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing a structure in a human patient intended for radiation therapy.
• The files are used to generate a first and second volume model, defined by the first and second electronic file respectively.

• The volume models are compared to identify common volume elements in common to both of the first and second volume models, missing volume elements of the first volume model that are not in the second volume model, and extra volume elements of the second volume model that are not in the first volume model.

• A measure of a conformance between the three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing the structure defined by the first and second electronic files is then output based on a metric method measuring numbers of missing volume elements and extra volume elements.

• The metric method may provide a summation of a first function based on the missing volume elements and a second function based on the extra volume elements, so that the metric method increases monotonically with increased missing volume elements and extra volume elements.

• The electronic computer may display a cross-sectional image through the first and second volume models along a user-defined cross-sectional plane separately identifying the common volume elements, missing volume elements, and extra volume elements by different colors.

• The stored program may further receive a third electronic file providing a cross-sectional image of patient tissue at the user-defined cross-sectional plane, and the cross-sectional images through the first and second volume models may be displayed superimposed on the cross-sectional image of patient tissue obtained from a third electronic file.

• The metric method may be a combination of: a constant value, a linear function of a number of error volume elements with distance, and an exponential function of the number of error volume elements with distance; wherein the error volume elements are missing volume elements and/or extra volume elements.",0

• • Summary of the Invention
• • Disclosed is a method of tracking a specimen acquired from a patient. The method comprises:
• • Storing in a computer storage a first machine-readable code present on an identification (ID) means worn by a patient;
• • Storing in the computer storage a second machine-readable code associated with an order to obtain a specimen from the patient;
• • Storing in the computer storage a third machine-readable code present on an identification (ID) means worn by a specimen-taker;

• • Following steps (a)-(c), selecting from a plurality of specimen containers having machine-readable codes that are unique to each other preapplied thereto one specimen container including a fourth machine-readable code preapplied thereto;

• • In response to an electronic reading means reading and dispatching to a processor of the computer the first—fourth machine-readable codes present on the ID means worn by the patient, present on the order, present on the ID means worn by the specimen-taker, and present on the specimen container, respectively, and in response to the processor determining that the first machine-readable code and the second machine-readable code are related to the same patient, the processor causing said first—fourth machine-readable codes to be stored in the computer storage in a relational manner and the processor of the computer causing a signal to be generated to acquire a specimen from the patient and to place the acquired specimen in the container; and

• • Responsive to the processor receiving a signal that the specimen has been placed in the container following step (e), the processor causing an indication thereof to be stored in the computer storage in a relational manner with said first—fourth machine-readable codes.
• • Each machine-readable code can be unique of the other machine-readable codes.

• • Step (f) can include the processor determining whether the signal of step (f) is received within a predetermined time interval of the processor generating the signal of step (e) and storing an indication thereof in the computer storage in a relational manner with said first—fourth machine-readable codes.
• • Each machine-readable code can comprise a unique barcode.

332,"  <summary>
• Waveguide holograms (WGHs) are used for controlled illumination of objects, including holograms and spatial light modulators (SLMs).
• Non-uniformity of the diffracted wavefront in the direction of propagation can be compensated for by exposing a photographic emulsion to the beam without compensation.
• The photographic negative absorbs most where the beam is brightest, and therefore, upon subsequent illumination through the negative, the wavefront passing is uniform.
• WGHs can achieve high diffraction efficiency (of order approaching 0.99), however, high efficiencies over large area holograms requires careful design.
• With a laser illuminated single-mode waveguide hologram, alignment of the laser beam is critical, leading to lack of ruggedness.
• Non-uniformity of the diffracted wavefront along the propagation direction is inevitable unless combated.
• Two basic architectures were used in experiments to record the WGH grating: a modified conventional holographic recording system and a modified SLM recording system.
• The modified conventional holographic recording system uses a cubic glass prism to create a reference beam with very steep angles.

• The modified SLM recording system uses a spatial light modulator to modulate the polarization of the light and create selective constructive and destructive interference between the directly emitted beam and the reflected beam.
</summary>

3. The photographic negative absorbs most where the beam is brightest, and therefore, upon subsequent illumination through the negative, the wavefront passing is uniform.
4. WGHs can achieve high diffraction efficiency (of order approaching 0.99), however, high efficiencies over large area holograms requires careful design.

* *Summary of the Invention* *

column2: 1. Implement a queue using a tree-shaped data structure in which the nodes have a given maximum size and the updates are made by copying the path from the root to the point of updating.
2. Additions and deletions are made in such a way that the leaf node remains at the same hierarchy level of the tree-shaped data structure.
3. The tree structure is symmetrical, which means that it can be inverted in constant time and space regardless of the length of the queue.
4. The queue can be implemented in a functional environment using a separate header node that contains three elements, each of which may be empty or contain a pointer.

338,"  <summary>
* Summary of the Invention

column2: + The invention relates to a technique of easily and quickly determining the optimum value of feedback gain used for calculating correction amount in feedback control.

+ The method of determining feedback gain according to the invention comprises provisionally determining a predetermined value of a feedback gain, executing feedback control using the provisionally determined feedback gain, detecting an error between a designated value and an actual value of the subject of control during the execution of the second step, calculating an evaluation value indicative of the character of feedback control according to the error detected in the third step, and repeatedly executing the second to fourth steps a plurality of times after provisionally determining a new feedback gain value different from the previous value.

+ The invention provides a method of determining feedback gain which permits determining the proper value of feedback gain both easily and accurately, in a short period of time and irrespective of the kind of the subject of control.

column1: * First Embodiment

column2: + The method of determining feedback gain according to the invention is applied to the running control of an AGV.

+ The construction of the AGV in this embodiment includes front wheels as steering wheels and rear wheels as drive wheels, and a steering module and a drive module are provided for the steering and drive wheels, respectively.

+ The steering module is controlled by a steering angle controller, and the drive module and brake module are controlled by a vehicle speed controller. The steering angle controller and vehicle speed controller are controlled by a central processor.

+ The central processor is a computer system including a central processing unit (CPU), and a memory section having a ROM and a RAM. The CPU, RAM, and ROM are interconnected by data buses for mutual data transfer.

+ The lateral deviation detector includes a sensor having a pick-up coil, and it detects by electromagnetic induction an induction wire which is laid on a running surface along the running course of the AGV.

+ The central processor executes a predetermined calculation process according to the inputted signals, and according to the result of the calculation process, the central processor outputs a control signal to the steering angle controller and the vehicle speed controller.
+ The flow of a signal in the running control system",0

340,"  <summary>
* Summary of the invention
* * Main objects and advantages

* Providing a method and device for detecting elementary particles that can detect both individual particles and integrate count rates, without knowing in advance count or signal rates to be expected.
* Enabling the detection of signals or pulses generated by elementary particles irrespectively of a, previous restriction as required in the prior art.
* Simplifying the distinction of small-size signals relative to a base quantity, for instance a base voltage or a base current.
* Providing a joint method and device for detecting individual particles and integrating count rates, in particular upon exceeding of a given threshold value for signal rates.
* Allowing a reliable detection or evaluation of small-size signals.
* Enabling the detection of uncharged particles by providing a detector material doped or coated with a converter material for the detection of uncharged particles.
* Detecting particles over very wide ranges of possible signal or count rates, or large bandwidths, using a material enabling fast charge transport at room temperature, such as diamond.
* Additional objects and advantages
* Preventing a leakage current in a high-voltage cable possibly having a large length from being detected.
* Enabling the measuring or detecting of individual particles at low rates or frequencies, in particular as a function of the signal rate actually occurring during measuring.

* Providing an adjustment in view of a separate, or optionally also simultaneous, detection of individual signals or pulses as well as an integration of each of a plurality thereof for detecting an averaged value over an extended period of time.

* Allowing the use of a device according to the invention for detecting particles in particle accelerators, in reactor installations, in diagnostic devices such as X-ray devices, CT devices or the like.
</summary>

* * Tribo Charge of Toner
* Below are three points that describe the relationship between the inactivity time and the tribo charge of the toner:
* 1. The tribo charge of the toner decreases with the increase in inactivity time.
* 2. The relationship between the inactivity time and the tribo charge of the toner can be approximated by a power law.
* 3. The constant C in the power law equation is dependent on the age of the toner and relative humidity (RH).
* Below are four sub-points that provide more detail on each of the above points:
* 1. The tribo charge of the toner decreases with the increase in inactivity time.
* 2. The relationship between the inactivity time and the tribo charge of the toner can be approximated by a power law.
* 3. The constant C in the power law equation is dependent on the age of the toner and relative humidity (RH).
* 4. An exemplary value of C is -0.02.
</summary>",0

• Repeaterless trunk and branch fiber optic ring network
• Incorporating essential structures supporting and powering in-line optical amplifiers
• Branch assembly
• Hub assembly with remote pumping
• Hub assembly without remote pumping
• Branch powered fiber optic communication system segment
• FIG. 1 is a block diagram of a repeaterless trunk and branch fiber optic ring network, incorporating the essential structures supporting and powering in-line optical amplifiers
• FIG. 2 is a block diagram of a branch assembly
• FIG. 3 is a block diagram of a repeaterless branch powered fiber optic communication system segment

• The present invention is a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and remotely supplying energy to those optical amplifiers over the same branch cables that also distribute communications signals

• The invention utilizes the branch fiber optic cable, along which communications signals are transmitted and received, to further unidirectionally transmit optical energy at a wavelength other than that of signal wavelength
• The optical energy is used as a power source for an optical amplifier, which is located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit
• Signal amplification is thereby provided without the use of conventional optical repeaters

• The combination of hub assemblies optically connected via a telecommunications cable trunk in a ring topology, with cable stations extracting and inserting trunk communication signals through branch fiber optic cables, has the following advantages: (i) a single optical fiber cable trunk cut maintains full connectivity along the trunk and to all cable stations via their respective branch fiber optic cables; (ii) branch fiber optic cable cuts simply isolate the associated cable station without compromising ring integrity, this aspect being especially important since branch fiber optic cable cuts are more susceptible to failure by severing since they are typically located in shallower water than the optical fiber cable trunk; (iii) by virtue of its trunk and branch structure, such networks respect the sovereignty concerns that often arise in under",0

356,"  <summary>
* Invention provides a method for facilitating communication between a finder of an article and an owner of the article.
* Aspects of the invention include providing a unique ID to the owner, associating the ID with owner contact information, and forwarding communications from the finder to the owner.
* The invention overcomes disadvantages of prior systems by providing a timely and anonymous communication channel between the finder and the owner.
* Steps of the method include:
* Providing a unique ID to the owner.
* Allowing the owner to register an association between the ID and owner contact information.
* Forwarding communications from the finder to the owner where the finder provides as little information as the communication and the unique ID to a virtual locale.
* Other aspects of the invention include:
* Allowing the owner to associate the ID and a virtual locale with the article.
* Providing a virtual locale, a database for storing an association between owner contact information and a unique ID, and a module for forwarding finder communications to the owner.
</summary>",0
357,"  <summary>Foil Electron Multiplier Design</summary>
* * Gain of the Foil Electron Multiplier

column2: + **1.** The gain of the foil electron multiplier can be modeled as a series of discrete dynodes and can therefore be represented by Equation 1.
+ **2.** The gain of the foil electron multiplier is proportional to the number of foil stages and the voltage applied to each stage.
+ **3.** The gain of the foil electron multiplier can be increased by increasing the number of foil stages or by increasing the voltage applied to each stage.
+ **4.** The gain of the foil electron multiplier can be limited by the number of foil stages and the voltage applied to each stage.

column1: * * Secondary Electron Emission Yield

column2: + **1.** The secondary electron emission yield (γ SE ) is a measure of the number of secondary electrons emitted per incident particle.
+ **2.** The secondary electron emission yield (γ SE ) is a function of the energy of the incident particle and the material of the foil.
+ **3.** The secondary electron emission yield (γ SE ) can be increased by using a material with a high secondary electron emission yield.
+ **4.** The secondary electron emission yield (γ SE ) can be decreased by using a material with a low secondary electron emission yield.

column1: * * Foil Thickness and Accelerating Potential

column2: + **1.** The foil thickness (τ) affects the secondary electron emission yield (γ SE ) and the gain of the foil electron multiplier.
+ **2.** The accelerating potential (V S ) applied to each foil stage affects the gain of the foil electron multiplier.
+ **3.** The optimal foil thickness and accelerating potential depend on the material of the foil and the desired gain.
+ **4.** The foil thickness and accelerating potential can be adjusted to optimize the gain of the foil electron multiplier.",0

column1: 361,"  <summary>
* * Image Sensor
* 1. Field of the Invention
* * CCD image sensors
* * Typical charge-coupled device (CCD) image sensors are formed on flat, circular semiconductor substrates known as wafers.
* * Image sensor elements are fabricated on either a top or bottom surface of the wafer by means of various doping layers of several microns in depth.
* * Upon completion of the image sensor elements, the die is cut from the wafer and mounted in a package where either the top or bottom surface is exposed for illumination.
* * Problem in using this image sensor in certain applications; for example, the sensor cannot be used in apparatus where it is desired to simultaneously image two opposing surfaces.
* * Invention relates to an image sensor, and more particularly, to an image sensor which includes multiple imaging planes.
* * Summary of the Invention

* * It is an object of the present invention to overcome the problems in the prior art discussed above by providing an image sensor in which information can be recorded through an edge surface of the sensor.
</summary>
<level1>

• • The invention relates to a method for fabricating a structure useful in semiconductor circuitry, comprising:
• • Growing a buffer layer of non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide layer directly or indirectly on a semiconductor substrate; and
• • Depositing a Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide on the buffer layer.

• • The non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide is less than about 10 nm thick, and the Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide is epitaxially grown on the non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide.
• • Both the non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide and the Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide are ferroelectric oxides and/or titanates.
• • The non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide is barium strontium titanate, and the Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide is lead zirconate titanate.
• • Both the non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide and the Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide may be epitaxially grown.
• • Alternately, the structure may comprise:
• • A buffer layer of non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide layer directly or indirectly on a semiconductor substrate; and
• • A Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide on the buffer layer.

column2: + The present invention provides a system for initiating a collaborative work-share environment between two or more parties to a telephone call without complex setup processes.

column2: 1. The invention relates to a dual mode mobile terminal for selectively connecting to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN).
2. The mobile terminal has a first network module and a second network module for connecting the WWAN and the WLAN, respectively.
3. The WWAN contains a plurality of first base stations, and the WLAN contains at least one second base station for gathering service information of the first base stations.
4. The mobile terminal selects one of the first base stations as a serving base station according to the service information to connect the WWAN.
5. The service information contains signal strength, channel information, and base station identity codes of the first base stations.
6. The mobile terminal can skip some of the connection setup time when the mobile terminal starts to connect the WWAN by using the information in the service information.

• • • Objects of the Invention
• • • The present invention relates to an apparatus for the preparation of foam sheet samples for microscopic examination.
• • • The invention relates to an apparatus that permits a precisely measured laboratory foam sheet cross-sectional specimen to be prepared.
• • • The apparatus includes a base structure for stabilization of the device and a clamping arrangement to grasp the foam sheet specimen without damaging it.
• • • Description of the Preferred Embodiment
• • • The apparatus consists of a base plate, upright support columns, a saddle bar, a clamp bar, and a hand nut.
• • • The foam sample is prepared for use by cutting it to a rectangular configuration and positioning it between the support bar and the clamp bar.
• • • The hand nut is used to move the clamp bar against the support bar, removing any curvature or curl from the foam sample.
• • • The razor blade is used to cut the foam sample to a precise length, and the hand nut is moved to the next stop position to raise the top edge of the foam sample by 0.004 inch.
• • • The apparatus provides a precise and efficient way to prepare foam sheet samples for microscopic examination.",0

* * Summary of the Invention
One of the objects of our invention is to provide an individually fitted helmet liner which may be fitted to a wearer's head rapidly and in a simple manner.
Another object of our invention is to provide an individually fitted helmet liner which may be refitted to accommodate a changed head size.
Still another object of our invention is to provide an individually fitted helmet liner which has uniform and hence predictable structural characteristics.
A further object of our invention is to provide an individually fitted helmet liner which does not require trimming after fitting.
Still another object of our invention is to provide an individually fitted helmet liner which is relatively simple and inexpensive to manufacture.
A further object of our invention is to provide an individually fitted helmet liner which resists the tendency to shift position on the wearer's head.

Finally, our invention contemplates a helmet liner in which a plurality of layers, each of which consists of an elastic thermoplastic sheet formed with an array of pockets, are arranged in superposed contacting relationship with one another, with the pockets being open and unfilled to allow their deformation in response to compressive contact with an adjacent layer.
* * Brief Description of the Drawings
FIG. 1 is a perspective view of a helmet incorporating our individually fitted liner.
FIG. 2 is an enlarged fragmentary section of a peripheral portion of the liner of the helmet shown in FIG. 1.
FIG. 3 is an enlarged fragmentary section of a central portion of our helmet, showing the relative arrangement of the outer shell and the thermoplastic liner.
FIG. 4 is a perspective view of the inner thermoplastic liner of the helmet shown fragmentarily in FIG. 3.

389,"  <summary>
* *Summary of the Invention* *

The present invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device, particularly, an insulated gate (MOS) field effect semiconductor device having a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
* *Object of the Invention* *
To provide a method of fabricating a semiconductor device by which the controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall is improved.
* *Embodiments* *

FIGS. 2A to 2D illustrate a first embodiment of the present invention, wherein a polycrystalline silicon layer is deposited on an oxide film formed on a gate electrode, and the polycrystalline silicon is anisotropically etched to form a portion on the gate sidewall.

FIGS. 3A to 3C illustrate a second embodiment of the invention, wherein a gate electrode is formed with an oxide film, and the oxide film is used as a mask for injecting ions of a desired conductivity type into the semiconductor substrate to form a high concentration region.
* *Advantages* *

The present invention provides a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device that allows for improved controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, and thus improved device performance.

The invention also provides a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device that can reduce the risk of hot carrier injection into the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, which can degrade device performance.
</summary>",0

393,"  <summary>
* Summary of the invention:

column2: + The invention relates to a process and an apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine.
+ The detection process involves using at least one optical checking element, such as a camera, to detect an image of a plurality of cigarettes located in the cigarette magazine.
+ The image is evaluated by an image-processing device, and if there is a deviation from a reference image and/or from at least one reference value, an error signal is produced.

+ The elimination process involves ejecting a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to an ejecting unit, in reaction to the detection of a defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarette.
+ The number of cigarettes ejected is large enough for a transversely located cigarette to be ejected in full.

column1: * Key features of the invention:

column2: + The use of an optical checking element to detect the image of the cigarettes in the magazine.
+ The use of an image-processing device to evaluate the image and detect any deviations.
+ The use of an ejecting unit to eject the cigarettes in the event of a deviation.
+ The provision of a plurality of ejecting units arranged in the region of the magazine.
+ The use of a housing to fix the ejecting unit in place.
+ The use of a connecting rod to connect the ejector to the housing.
+ The provision of a chute to guide the ejected cigarettes.
+ The use of a plurality of ejecting zones and evaluation zones to improve the detection and elimination process.
+ The use of a camera to monitor the cigarette magazine and detect any defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes.

397,  <summary>
* *Battery Cell Rebalancing*

column2: + *Cell Imbalance Correction*: Battery cells may become imbalanced due to manufacturing tolerances, age, temperature, etc.
+ *Rebalancing Algorithm*: An algorithm is used to detect cell imbalance and rebalance the cells to correct the imbalance.

column1: </summary>
* *Cell Imbalance Correction*

column2: + *Cell Voltage Measurement*: The voltage of each cell is measured to detect imbalance.
+ *Cell Bleeding Down*: The voltage of the cells is reduced by bleeding down the cells with the highest voltage until the voltage of all cells is approximately equal.
+ *Cell Charging*: The cells are charged to full capacity to correct for any imbalance caused during discharge.

column1: </summary>
* *Rebalancing Algorithm*

column2: + *Time Allocation*: The algorithm determines how much time to spend on rebalancing and charging the battery.
+ *Cell Capacity Determination*: The algorithm determines the maximum capacity of each cell based on the change in capacity over time.
+ *Energy Content Determination*: The algorithm determines the energy content of each cell based on the voltage and current associated with the power stored.",0

column1: 398,"  <summary>

The invention relates to an AC-to-DC converter as a lamp power supply that converts an AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage at a predetermined value set by a potentiometer. The output lamp has neither low frequency flicker nor high frequency flicker, thus reducing eye strain and preventing myopia. The invention provides an AC-to-DC voltage converter as power supply for a lamp, including an input power source, an input protection circuit, an EMI filter, a rectifier, a filter, a converter, an output filter, a lamp, a start circuit, a control circuit, an input monitor circuit, and an output protection circuit.
The key features of the invention include:
1. The input voltage source comes from line voltage, usually low frequency AC voltage such as 110V, 60Hz or 220V, 50Hz.
2. The input protection circuit includes an overcurrent protection circuit that clamps the input voltage to a predetermined value to prevent overvoltage damage on the power supply circuit.
3. The EMI filter prevents high-frequency components from entering the low-frequency input power supply.
4. The converter converts the AC voltage to a varying magnitude DC voltage, and the sampling circuit collects the voltage signal proportional to the output voltage.

5. The control circuit regulates the output voltage at a constant value while adjusting the duty cycle or frequency response to the input voltage to prevent overvoltage damage on the power supply circuit.
6. The output filter prevents high-frequency components from entering the output lamp, and the start circuit supplies power to the control circuit to startup the power supply before stable operation.

7. The input monitor circuit monitors the input voltage and sends a signal to the control circuit to control the duty cycle or frequency response to the input voltage to prevent overvoltage damage on the power supply circuit.

8. The lamp can use any kind of lamp, and the output protection circuit includes an overvoltage protection circuit, an overcurrent protection circuit, and an overtemperature protection circuit to prevent damage to the power supply circuit.

* LDA and IRC section 4911 and 162(e) differ in their coverage of federal officials:

column2: + LDA covers only contacts with federal officials, while IRC definitions cover contacts with officials in other levels of government as well as attempts to influence the public through grassroots lobbying.
+ IRC section 162(e) provides an exception for contacts with local legislative officials regarding legislation of direct interest to the organization.

column1: * Differences in coverage of state and local government officials:

column2: + Both IRC definitions cover contacts with state government officials to influence state legislation, while LDA does not.

+ Both IRC definitions cover contacts with local government officials to influence local government legislation, but IRC section 162(e) provides an exception for contacts with local legislative officials regarding legislation of direct interest to the organization.

column1: * Grassroots lobbying:

column2: + LDA covers only lobbying of federal government officials, so organizations using the LDA definition would not include any information in their lobbying reports about lobbying state and local officials.

+ Both IRC definitions cover grassroots lobbying, such as television commercials; newspaper advertisements; and direct mail campaigns to influence federal, state, and local legislation, including referenda and ballot initiatives.

column1: * Differences in the definitions of lobbying-related terms:

column2: + LDA and IRC definitions differ in their coverage of certain lobbying-related terms, such as ""lobbying contact"" and ""grassroots lobbying.""

+ IRC section 4911 defines ""lobbying contact"" as any face-to-face or written communication with any covered executive branch official, while LDA defines it as any oral or written communication with a covered official.

column1: * Impact of differences on registration and reporting:

column2: + Differences in the definitions of lobbying-related terms may affect who must register with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives and what lobbying expenses and related information must be included in their reports.
+ The number of organizations that reported using the LDA and IRC definitions to calculate their lobbying expenses for July through December 1997 and the lobb",0

403,"  <summary>

* Surface transportation programs face challenges in effectively addressing transportation challenges due to lack of clarity in federal role and goals, lack of links between programs and outcomes, and insufficient funding.
* Key transportation challenges include increasing congestion and growing freight demand, which require a more focused and performance-based approach to surface transportation programs.

* Principles for restructuring and funding surface transportation programs include creating well-defined goals based on identified areas of national interest, establishing and clearly defining the federal role, incorporating performance and accountability into funding decisions, and ensuring fiscal sustainability.

* Proposals to restructure and fund surface transportation programs should consider areas of national interest and specific goals for federal involvement, define the federal role in relation to state and local governments, and establish performance measures to hold grantees accountable for achieving results.

* Tools and approaches to improve results and emphasize return on investment include using economic analysis, requiring grantees to conduct post-project evaluations, creating incentives to better utilize existing infrastructure, providing states and localities with greater flexibility to use certain tools, and requiring maintenance-of-effort provisions in grants.
</summary>

* *Mexico has sought to combat the growing power of criminal groups in the country for over a decade, with a national priority since 2006.
* *The struggle against these groups has become a national priority, with efforts to disrupt their operations and target their leadership structures.
* *Firearms are a key component of these criminal organizations' power, with the majority of weapons seized in Mexico traced back to the United States.
* *In 2009-2014, 70% of firearms seized in Mexico were traced to the US, with a decline in the number of firearms traced since 2011.
* *Drug trafficking organizations prefer high-caliber weapons, including assault rifles and machine guns, which are often converted from semi-automatic to fully automatic.
* *ICE has seized 5,951 firearms destined for Mexico in the last 6 years, with long guns (including rifles and shotguns) making up 39% of seizures.
* *ATF has taken steps to combat firearms trafficking to Mexico, including implementation of Demand Letter 3, which requires dealers to report multiple sales of certain rifles.
</summary>

+ BJS (or its predecessor) took the lead in encouraging states to computerize criminal records and ensure conformity with evolving FBI standards.

column1: * NCHIP was established in 1995 to enhance public safety by enhancing the nation’s criminal history records systems.

column2: + NCHIP provides funding to states to improve their criminal history records and make them accessible nationally.

column1: * States have made progress in automating criminal history records and making them accessible nationally.

409,"  • Internal Control Weaknesses:

• • SEC’s financial statements were fairly stated in all material respects for fiscal years 2007 and 2006, but the weaknesses in internal control noted above may adversely affect decisions by SEC management that is based, in whole or in part, on information that is inaccurate because of this weakness.
• • In addition, unaudited financial information reported by SEC, including performance information, may also contain misstatements resulting from these weaknesses.
• Information Security Weaknesses:

• • SEC had one material weakness and three significant control deficiencies in internal control, which may adversely affect decisions by SEC management that is based, in whole or in part, on information that is inaccurate because of this weakness.

• • Weaknesses in information security controls can impair the accuracy, completeness, and timeliness of information used by management and increase the potential for undetected material misstatements in the agency’s financial statements.
• Period-End Financial Reporting Process:

• • SEC’s period-end financial reporting process for recording transactions, maintaining account balances, and preparing financial statements and disclosures are supported to varying degrees by a collection of automated systems that are not integrated or compatible with its general ledger system.

• • This processing complicates review of the transactions and greatly increases the risk that the transactions are not recorded completely, properly, or consistently, ultimately affecting the reliability of the data presented in the financial statements.
• Accounts Receivable for Disgorgements and Penalties:
• • SEC recognizes a receivable when SEC is designated in an order or a final judgment to collect the assessed disgorgements, penalties, and interest against violators of federal securities laws.

• • At September 30, 2007, the gross amount of disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable was $330 million, with a corresponding allowance of $266 million resulting in a net receivable of $64 million.
• Transaction Fee Revenue:
• • SEC collects securities transaction fees paid by self-regulatory",0

* The Postal Service is the largest civilian employer in the US, with over 765,000 employees.
* The Service includes various positions, such as craft employees, EAS management-level positions, and PCES.
* The Service has a commitment to equal employment opportunities and diversity, with a required promotion procedure and a diversity development department.
* The Service developed an action plan to address diversity issues raised by Aguirre International, which found that women and minorities were underrepresented in EAS 17 and above positions.

* The study compared the representation of women and minorities in the Postal Service workforce with the 1990 Census CLF data, and found that black and Asian men and women, and Hispanic men were underrepresented.

* The study also found that white and Hispanic women, and Native American men and women were underrepresented in the workforce, and that the representation of women and minorities increased over time in EAS 17 and above positions.
</summary>

* New programs and initiatives in HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget proposal:

column2: + *1. HUD is proposing an increase in its Section 8 housing assistance program, with a total request of $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority.
+ *2. The program includes a $4.2 billion advance appropriation for fiscal year 2001.
+ *3. HUD's CDBG Program provides grants for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income people, prevent or eliminate slum or blight, or meet urgent community needs.
+ *4. The program has a $428 million set-aside for 10 projects or initiatives, including Metropolitan Job Links, Homeownership Zones, and a Citizens Volunteer Housing Corps.
+ *5. HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs that were not funded in fiscal year 1999.
+ *6. These include Community Outreach Partnership, Hispanic Serving Institutions, and Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

+ *7. HUD's budget justification shows that funding needs to cover contract shortfalls will be met by existing unexpended balances, but does not identify the estimated funding shortfall or the amount of unexpended balances available in each of the project- and tenant-based components.
+ *8. GAO has raised questions about HUD's capacity to manage the increase in new programs and initiatives, given the reform of its organizational structure.
+ *9. HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget proposal raises issues about the basis for the contract renewal costs for the Section 8 project-based program and the basis for renewal costs beyond 2000.

* Removal of Aliens

column2: + Aliens subject to removal from the US total 12 million, according to Pew Research Center
+ DHS removed 102,340 apprehended aliens in 2005, or about 8% of the 1.3 million apprehended by DHS
+ ICE policies and procedures govern the removal process, which involves six phases: initial encounter, apprehension, charging, detention, removal proceedings, and final removal

column1: * Discretion in Removal Process

column2: + ICE officers exercise discretion throughout the removal process, but their ability to do so is limited in certain cases, such as when dealing with investigation targets (e.g., criminal aliens)
+ Officers can exercise discretion in apprehending and charging aliens who are not investigation targets, and can consider factors such as humanitarian concerns and ICE priorities
+ ICE headquarters officials noted that officers at field offices near the US-Mexico border employ voluntary departure generally due to their proximity to the border

column1: * Training and Guidance

column2: + ICE officers rely on formal and on-the-job training and guidance provided by supervisors to inform their decision-making regarding alien apprehensions and removals
+ ICE has recently begun undertaking reviews of its policies and procedures to ensure they are up-to-date and effective.",0

Ground ambulance services are provided by various organizations, including independent and freestanding, affiliated with institutions, and government-based providers.
The following is a summary of the key points from the text:
Ground ambulance services are provided by different types of organizations, including:
* Independent and freestanding providers
* Affiliated with institutions (such as hospitals or fire departments)
* Government-based providers
These organizations have different structures, staffing types, and revenue sources.
The following are the sub-points for each bullet point:
Ground ambulance services are provided by different types of organizations:
* Independent and freestanding providers: These providers are not affiliated with any institution and are responsible for their own operations and finances.

* Affiliated with institutions (such as hospitals or fire departments): These providers are affiliated with an institution, such as a hospital or fire department, and share resources and operational costs with the institution.
* Government-based providers: These providers are government-funded and responsible for providing ground ambulance services to the community.
These organizations have different structures, staffing types, and revenue sources:
* Different structures: Independent and freestanding providers have more autonomy in their operations and finances compared to affiliated and government-based providers.
* Different staffing types: Each type of provider has different staffing requirements, with independent and freestanding providers typically having more flexibility in their staffing levels.

* Different revenue sources: Affiliated and government-based providers may have more reliable revenue sources compared to independent and freestanding providers, which may have more variable revenue sources.
The level of government support and the availability of resources can affect the cost of ground ambulance services:
* Government support: Government-based providers may have more reliable revenue sources and access to resources compared to independent and freestanding providers.
* Availability of resources: The availability of resources, such as funding and equipment, can affect the cost of ground ambulance services provided by different types of organizations.
The Medicare payment formula for ground ambul",0
418,"  • SRC I ammunition is a sensitive conventional ammunition that requires special handling and accountability.
• The Department of Defense (DOD) is responsible for managing and accounting for SRC I ammunition, which includes tracking its location and inventory.
• The Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Logistics & Materiel Readiness is the department-wide office responsible for leading the development of DOD policies regarding SRC I ammunition.
• The Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force have roles and responsibilities in managing and accounting for SRC I ammunition.

• The Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command tracks the movement of SRC I ammunition, and the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition.",0

• Social Security Administration (SSA) has a long history of protecting individuals' privacy
• SSA's disclosure policy allows sharing of personal information with law enforcement under certain conditions

• Disclosure of personal information to law enforcement is more restrictive than Privacy Act and disclosure policies of most federal agencies
• SSA's disclosure policy is contained in 20 C.F.R. Part 401 and is promulgated through regulations outlined in its ""Program Operations Manual System"" (POMS) and Emergency Messages

420,"  • RCRA establishes a national policy to minimize present and future threats to human health and the environment from hazardous waste.

• RCRA governs the management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal, including identification and listing of hazardous waste, criteria for classification of waste, and application of requirements to remediation waste.
• EPA has identified three RCRA requirements that create disincentives for cleanup of contaminated sites: land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permitting requirements.
• Land disposal restrictions prohibit parties from disposing of hazardous waste on land unless it has been treated to minimize threats to human health and the environment.

• Treatment standards under RCRA are costly and complex, particularly for remediation waste, as they require parties to use technologies that are more stringent and expensive than necessary to protect human health and the environment.
• Complying with minimum technological requirements for facilities, such as incinerators and landfills, can be expensive and may add unnecessary costs for remediation waste.
• Obtaining a RCRA permit can be time-consuming and costly, particularly for facilities that are not in the business of transporting, storing, or disposing of hazardous waste.

• EPA and state cleanup managers have identified problems with the treatment standards and permitting requirements under RCRA, including the need for more research on appropriate technologies for remediation waste and the need for more streamlined permit processes.

• The application of RCRA requirements to remediation waste has led parties to base their cleanup decisions on considerations of meeting treatment standards rather than on the risks posed by the waste.",0
421,"  <summary>
* Medicare program integrity activities were subsumed under Medicare’s general administrative budget and performed by insurance companies until 1996.
* Funding for program integrity activities was constrained due to budget procedures imposed under the Budget Enforcement Act of 1990.
* HIPAA provided dedicated funding for program integrity activities starting in fiscal year 1997.
* MIP funds are used to support program safety efforts, including audits, medical review, secondary payer, and benefit integrity.
* Provider education is the largest program integrity activity in terms of funding.
* CMS increased funding for provider education in fiscal year 2002 to address provider concerns about increased burden in medical review process.
* CMS tracks ROI for medical review and secondary payer activities, with secondary payer having an ROI of $37 for every dollar spent.
* Audit’s reported contribution to ROI fell to almost zero due to implementation of prospective payment systems.
</summary>
Level 1:
* Medicare program integrity activities were subsumed under Medicare’s general administrative budget and performed by insurance companies until 1996.
* Funding for program integrity activities was constrained due to budget procedures imposed under the Budget Enforcement Act of 1990.
* HIPAA provided dedicated funding for program integrity activities starting in fiscal year 1997.
Level 2:
* MIP funds are used to support program safety efforts, including audits, medical review, secondary payer, and benefit integrity.
* Provider education is the largest program integrity activity in terms of funding.
* CMS increased funding for provider education in fiscal year 2002 to address provider concerns about increased burden in medical review process.
Note: Each bullet point and sub-bullet point is indented once, and each level of indentation is indicated by a tab character (\t).",0
422,"  • Passenger and checked baggage screening in the US has been a concern for over two decades.
• • In 1978, screeners failed to detect 13% of dangerous objects, and in 1987, this number increased to 20%.
• • • In recent tests, screeners have failed to detect threatening objects at an alarming rate.
• TSA was created in 2001 to oversee and improve security procedures at US airports.
• • • TSA has set standards for passenger and checked baggage screening and has implemented various training programs for screeners.
• • • However, despite these efforts, screeners continue to struggle with detecting dangerous objects.
• • • One reason for this is the lack of effective training programs for screeners.
• • • TSA has implemented various training programs, but these programs have not been enough to improve screener performance.
• • • Additionally, TSA has faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training for screeners.
• • • Despite these challenges, TSA continues to work towards improving passenger and checked baggage screening procedures.",0
423,"  <summary>
* IRS manages 25 call sites across the country, with 10,000 customer service representatives answering calls from taxpayers.
* IRS has not established a long-term goal for service level, instead setting annual funding levels and estimating service levels based on staffing levels.
* Call centers face challenges in recruiting, training, and retaining customer service representatives.
* IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy to identify growth sites for hiring representatives.
* Training representatives is a complex task due to the broad range of topics they must address.
* IRS provides standard training curriculum to all call sites, with incremental training over 3 years.
* Call centers face challenges in measuring and improving service levels.
* IRS is developing a strategic plan to set multi-year goals and measure progress.
* Other organizations set service-level goals based on customer needs and use benchmarking to measure performance.
* IRS recognizes the need to establish long-term goals and is considering adopting measures used by other organizations.
</summary>

column1: 424,"  <summary>
• Ginnie Mae is a government agency that operates as a unit of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)
• Ginnie Mae's primary market or sells them in the secondary market, where investors buy and sell mortgage-backed securities (MBS)
• Secondary market allows lenders to manage their liquidity needs, reduce interest rate risk, and generate funds for additional lending

• Ginnie Mae provides guarantees to investors, which allows them to receive timely payments of principal and interest on securities, regardless of whether the borrower makes the underlying mortgage payment or the issuer makes timely payments on the MBS
• Ginnie Mae has several different products, including Ginnie Mae I, Ginnie Mae II, and Multiclass Securities Program
• Ginnie Mae I requires that all pools contain similar types of mortgages with similar maturities and interest rates
• Ginnie Mae II permits pools to contain loans with more heterogeneous loans, such as adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs)
• Ginnie Mae Multiclass Securities Program allows investors to tailor the prepayment and interest rate risks associated with MBS to their investment goals
• Ginnie Mae does not receive appropriations or borrow money to finance its credit operations, but instead generates revenue exceeding its expenses, which reduces the federal budget deficit

• Ginnie Mae securities finance a large portion of FHA and VA loans, and Ginnie Mae issued $149.1 billion in MBS in fiscal year 2004, representing 91% of eligible loans insured or guaranteed by FHA and VA

• Ginnie Mae faces competition from other secondary market entities, such as the Federal Home Loan Banks, Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac, but these entities have limited or no involvement in Ginnie Mae's market
• Ginnie Mae's charter keeps it focused on a discrete portion of the MBS market, specifically loans made under FHA, VA, RHS, and PIH programs, and changes",0
