591,"  • The Millennium Challenge Account (MCA) is a new foreign aid program established by the US government in 2004, with a focus on countries that have demonstrated a commitment to good governance, economic growth, and poverty reduction.

• The MCA is designed to provide funding to countries based on their performance in three areas: ruling justly, investing in people, and promoting economic policies that stimulate enterprise and entrepreneurship.
• The MCA is different from other foreign aid programs in that it is tied to performance and results, and country eligibility is based on both poverty and governance indicators.

• The MCA has faced some challenges and controversies, including questions about its effectiveness, the role of the US Agency for International Development (USAID), and the potential impact on other global development aid funding levels.",0
592,"  <summary>
* *Summary of the Major Provisions of the 2012 Farm Bill* *
* *Comparison of the Senate-Passed and House Agriculture Committee-Approved Versions of the Farm Bill* *
I. Summary of the Major Provisions of the 2012 Farm Bill
A. Overview of the Farm Bill
* The 2012 farm bill, also known as the Agriculture Reform, Food and Jobs Act of 2012, was passed by the Senate and approved by the House Agriculture Committee
* The bill addresses various agricultural and food-related issues, including farm commodity support, conservation, trade, and nutrition programs
B. Key Provisions of the Senate-Passed Farm Bill
* Elimination of direct payments to farmers and consolidation of conservation programs
* Creation of a new revenue-based program called Agriculture Risk Coverage (ARC)
* Reauthorization of disaster programs for livestock and tree farmers
* Changes to the sugar program, including an increase in the import quota
C. Key Provisions of the House Agriculture Committee-Approved Farm Bill
* Revision of farm program support to include a choice between a counter-cyclical price program and a revenue program
* Consolidation of conservation programs and reduction in funding
* Creation of a new conservation program called the Agricultural Conservation Easement Program (ACEP)
II. Comparison of the Senate-Passed and House Agriculture Committee-Approved Versions of the Farm Bill
A. Differences in Farm Program Support

* The Senate-passed bill eliminates direct payments and consolidates conservation programs, while the House bill revises farm program support to include a choice between a counter-cyclical price program and a revenue program
B. Differences in Conservation Programs
* The Senate-passed bill consolidates conservation programs and reduces funding, while the House bill creates a new conservation program called ACEP
C. Differences in Trade Provisions
* The Senate-passed bill includes an amendment to place greater emphasis on improving the quality of food aid products, while the House bill retain",0

593,"  • Inland waterway system is a significant component of the nation's marine transportation system, carrying approximately 1/6 of the national volume of intercity cargo and 100% of the tonnage of bulk commodities.
• The system is funded through a fuel tax on commercial barges, with the revenue going into the Inland Waterways Trust Fund (IWTF).
• The IWTF has faced funding challenges in recent years due to increasing costs and a lack of appropriations, leading to a decrease in new project funding and a growing project backlog.
• Proposals have been made to address these challenges, including increasing the fuel tax, cost-sharing requirements, and reforms to the project planning process.",0

column1: 596,"  <summary>
* The Lacey Act was enacted in 1900 to address game poaching and wildlife laundering.
* The Lacey Act regulates the trade of wildlife and plants and makes penalties for violations.
* The 2008 amendments to the Lacey Act expanded the definition of plants to include any wild member of the plant kingdom and increased the value of U.S. wood exports.
* The 2008 amendments also require importers of all covered plants and plant products to submit an import declaration to U.S. Customs and Border Protection.
* The declaration must include information on the scientific name of any plant, the value of the plant or product, and the country of origin.
* The 2008 amendments also created special use designations (SUDs) to ease the burden of declarations.
* The implementation of the declaration requirements is related to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule (HTS) of the United States.
* APHIS has stated that it is not enforcing the declaration requirement for informal entries such as personal shipments.

* The 2008 amendments required a review of the declaration requirements and the effects of certain exclusions to the declaration requirements not more than two years after the enactment of the amendments.
</summary>
* The Lacey Act was enacted in 1900 to address game poaching and wildlife laundering.

597,"  <summary>
* Counter-cyclical assistance in the US agricultural sector
* 1. The term ""counter-cyclical"" refers to the provision of financial support to farmers during periods of low crop prices, with the aim of stabilizing farm income and encouraging production.

column2: + 2. The source document provides an overview of the history and evolution of counter-cyclical assistance in the US, including the various forms it has taken over time.
+ 3. The document highlights the importance of counter-cyclical assistance in supporting farmers during times of economic downturn, particularly in the wake of the 1996 Farm Bill.
+ 4. The document notes that counter-cyclical assistance is not a new concept, with examples of similar programs dating back to the 1930s.

column1: 2. The document goes on to provide a detailed analysis of the different forms of counter-cyclical assistance provided in the 2002 Farm Bill, including:

column2: + 5. Market-based counter-cyclical payments, which are tied to current market prices and are designed to provide support to farmers when prices are low.
+ 6. Direct payments, which are made directly to farmers based on historical production levels, regardless of current market prices.
+ 7. Target price deficiency payments, which are designed to provide support to farmers when prices are below a certain target price.
+ 8. Loan deficiency payments, which are made to farmers who participate in the federal loan program and are designed to provide support to farmers when prices are low.

column1: 3. The document also provides an analysis of the potential impact of counter-cyclical assistance on the US agricultural sector, including:

column2: + 9. The potential impact on farm income and profitability, particularly during times of economic downturn.
+ 10. The potential impact on trade and the global agricultural market, particularly in light of the World Trade Organization's (WTO) rules on agricultural subsidies.

598,"  • Since 2013, the US and Vietnam have been working on a 123 agreement to facilitate nuclear energy cooperation.

• • 2. Vietnam's nuclear energy program aims to meet 20-30% of the country's electricity needs by 2050.
• • 3. The country has been considering nuclear power as an option since the 1990s and has conducted several feasibility studies.
• • 4. Vietnam has signed an agreement with Russia to build two 1,200 MWe light-water reactors at the Ninh Thuan 1 power plant.
• • 5. The country is also exploring the possibility of developing a full fuel cycle capability, but has no plans to do so at present.
• • 6. The US and Vietnam have been working on a 123 agreement since 2013, which would facilitate nuclear energy cooperation between the two countries.",0
599,"  • 2005 saw little progress in resolving the North Korea nuclear issue.
• 2005 saw a series of key events, including:
•  •  • North Korea announced it had nuclear weapons and would indefinitely suspend its participation in the Six-Party Talks (February 10)
•  •  • North Korea asserted that it had the right to develop peaceful nuclear energy programs and demanded the return of U.S. nuclear weapons (April)
•  •  • North Korea launched a short-range missile into the East Sea (May)
•  •  • The United States and North Korea agreed to discuss Pyongyang's right to develop peaceful nuclear energy programs (July)
•  •  • The Six-Party Talks resumed in September, with a joint statement of principles agreed to in October

•  •  • The statement committed North Korea to abandoning all nuclear weapons and existing nuclear programs and returning at any early date to the treaty on the proliferation of nuclear weapons and to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards (October)

•  •  • The statement also provided for security assurances for North Korea, South Korea's commitment to provide 2 million kilowatts of electricity, and the U.S. and Japan's pledge to take steps toward normalization of relations with Pyongyang (October)
•  •  • The accomplishment was short-lived, however, as North Korea claimed it would return to the IAEAs Nonproliferation Treaty (NPT) only after it received an LWR from the United States (November)

•  •  • The U.S. and North Korea disagreed on the counterfeiting issue, with North Korea insisting that the imposition of sanctions on a Macau bank for allegedly laundering counterfeit U.S. dollars constituted a hostile action (November)

•  •  • Human rights in North Korea became a prominent issue, with the appointment of Jay Lefkowitz as the Special Envoy for Human Rights in North Korea and the U.S. Treasury Department's warning to banks about doing business with North Korea (September)",0

602,"  <summary>
* Sulfone - substituted anhydrides were synthesized and their reactivity studied.
* The anhydrides were found to be highly reactive towards imines, forming - and -lactams with high diastereoselectivity (>95:5).
* The carboxylic acids derived from the substituted succinic anhydrides were prone to decarboxylation, which was driven by heating.
* The -lactam acids derived from the glutaric anhydrides could not be intercepted, indicating a difference in reactivity compared to succinic anhydrides.
* The diastereoselectivity of the initial Mannich reaction was lower for the glutaric anhydrides compared to succinic anhydrides.
* The sulfone anhydrides were found to be highly robust and were used in the formal synthesis of a biologically active natural product.

605,"  <summary>
• Emp levels in the circulation of a model patient were reduced by 50% within 30 minutes of starting dialysis.
• Emp levels remained relatively constant over the duration of the study, with a final level of 29% of the initial concentration.
• The dialysate contained 5.7% of the original emp concentration at the end of 4 hours of dialysis.
• The experimental conditions achieve the same plasma level of emps as seen in human clinical disease (110 per ml).
• The observed emp clearance is likely a saturable phenomenon.
• Convection and pressure gradients were not modeled, as these interventions require replacement fluid and would confound emp measurement.
• Forced hindered diffusion via the application of convective and pressure forces coupled with replacement by emp-free fluid would likely sustain clearance.
• The low dialysate emp level and plateauing circulation emp level beyond 40 minutes suggest that emp sequestration occurs within the cvvh filter or tubing and is a saturable phenomenon.
• Frequent changing of the cvvh filter is a logical step that may overcome this limitation.
• More efficient and selective emp clearance can be realized by conjugating endothelium-specific antibodies to commercially available specialty cvvh filters (Aethlon Adapt).
• This approach would provide more selective binding sites and higher affinity for circulating emps.
• By combining a selective filter with convection and pressure gradients, emp clearance could likely be substantially prolonged.
</summary>",0

611,"  <summary>
• Mesenchymal hamartomas of the liver are rare benign tumors that can be classified into three types based on their imaging features: multiseptated cystic, mixed solid and cystic, and solid.
• The tumors are characterized by the presence of a cystic component with thin septa, irregular thick septa, or no septa, and a solid portion with variable attenuation.
• The cystic component shows low attenuation on a pre-contrast CT scan and enhances heterogeneously on contrast-enhanced CT.
• The solid portion shows variable attenuation and may contain small amounts of hepatocytes.
• The amount of hepatocytes in the solid portion is significantly different among the three types of tumors (p = 0.042).

• The other pathological findings, such as the amount of mesenchymal stroma, presence of bile duct or vessel proliferation, and age of the patients, are not significantly different among the three groups.
• The patients presented with abdominal distension, palpable mass, or incidentally detected tumor during US for other clinical indications.

• The serum level of alpha-fetoprotein, total and direct bilirubin level, alkaline phosphatase level, and level of transaminases (aspartate transaminase and alanine transaminase) were normal in all except two patients.
• The tumors occurred in the right lobe of the liver in nine patients and in the left lobe in four patients.
</summary>
• • Multiseptated cystic, mixed solid and cystic, and solid types of mesenchymal hamartomas can be identified based on their imaging features.
• • The cystic component shows low attenuation on a pre-contrast CT scan and enhances heterogeneously on contrast-enhanced CT.
• • The solid portion shows variable attenuation and may contain small amounts of hepatocytes.
• • The amount of hepatocytes in the solid portion is significantly different among the three types of tumors (p = 0.042).
• • The other pathological findings",0
612,"  <summary>
* Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects people of all ages, with higher prevalence in older adults and women.

column2: + RA prevalence varies across countries and regions, with higher prevalence in northern Europe and Italy.
+ The economic burden of RA is significant, with higher costs associated with more advanced disease and increased use of biological agents.
+ RA prevalence and incidence are expected to increase with aging population and tight adherence to diagnostic criteria.
+ Few studies have estimated the costs associated with RA in Italy before the availability of biological agents.

+ A retrospective, prevalence-based, multicenter, cost-of-illness study in 1998 evaluated direct, indirect, and intangible costs associated with RA in 200 patients aged 18-65 years in ten rheumatology institutes in Italy.
+ Indirect costs accounted for the largest part of disease management costs, and social costs (direct plus indirect costs) increased as RA worsened.
+ The estimated mean annual cost per patient in Europe with RA was around €12,902, with direct costs representing 43% of the total expenditure.
+ The structure of the costs of RA has changed over the years, with a substantial increase in direct costs largely as a result of the availability of newer, more costly biological agents.

The maxillary denture was sectioned from the midline and the gap created was filled with self-cure acrylic resin, while the mandibular denture was sectioned from the midline and the gap created was filled with self-cure acrylic resin.

• The maxillary hinged denture and the mandibular sectional (separate anterior removable segment) and hinged denture were placed in the patient's mouth, and the patient was recalled for follow-up visits to check for maintenance and adaptability with the dentures.
• The patient initially felt difficulty while placing and removal of the dentures from the oral cavity but with time, the patient got used to it.

• The techniques used for fabricating sectional and hinged tray/complete dentures include using smallest size edentulous stock tray with impression compound, border molding with each tray using low fusing compound, and incorporating wax rims over the denture bases.

column1: 616,"  <summary>
* Tibial adamantinoma is a rare slow-growing primary tumor of the bone.
* There is controversy regarding the relationship between osteofibrous dysplasia and adamantinoma.
* Clinical presentation is non-specific and can mimic other conditions.
* Diagnosis is challenging and requires a combination of imaging studies and histopathology.
* Metastasis to the lymph nodes is rare, and the best practice plan for management is not well established.
* Two cases of tibial adamantinoma are reported, one with metastasis to the inguinal lymph nodes and the other with metastasis to the lung.
* The first case had a history of previous surgical excision of a left tibial adamantinoma.
* The second case had a swelling in the left inguinal area that was initially diagnosed as a cutaneous eccrine carcinoma.
* Histopathological examination revealed the presence of basaloid cells with round vesicular nuclei and minimal cytoplasm.
* Immunohistochemistry confirmed the epithelial nature of the cells.
</summary>

617,"  <summary>
* Antireflection technology plays a crucial role in the fabrication of high-efficiency solar cells by increasing light coupling into the active region of devices.
* Nanostructures with a wide bandgap, such as ZnO, can be used as antireflective layers in solar cells.
* ZnO nanowhiskers (NWs) have been proposed as a promising antireflective layer for solar cells due to their high reflectivity and good potential for scale-up.
* The deposition temperature and time of ZnO NWs can be optimized for improving solar cell performances by controlling the density and length of the NWs.
* The reflection spectra of the samples were measured by a UV-Vis spectrophotometer, and the external quantum efficiency (EQE) of the final solar cells were obtained from the spectral responses.
* The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of the cells under dark and illumination conditions were measured using a standard solar simulator.
* ZnO NWs grown for different times (30, 45, and 60 min) can reduce the reflectivity of solar cells effectively in a large spectral range and improve the EQE in the corresponding range.
* Zno NWs grown for 45 min can improve the efficiency of solar cells by 3%, corresponding to their increment of short-circuit current density and fill factor.
* Long-time immersion of solar cells in aqueous solution during the ZnO NW growth process can deteriorate the solar cell performance drastically.
</summary>
<level 2>

column1: 622,"  • Schistosomiasis is a chronic and debilitating disease caused by the parasitic flatworm Schistosoma, with over 237 million people infected worldwide.
• Schistosomiasis is endemic in 77 countries and is transmitted through intermediate hosts such as snails and freshwater habitats.
• The schistosome life cycle involves the parasite migrating from the snail to the mammalian host, where it causes pathology and can lead to long-term health issues.
• The schistosome genome has been sequenced, revealing a complex evolutionary history and providing insights into the parasite's biology and drug resistance.
• The schistosome genome contains a large number of repetitive sequences, which can be used for population genetic studies and phylogenetic analysis.
• Comparative genomics of different Schistosoma species has revealed conserved features such as overall GC content, sequence identity, and the presence of repetitive elements.
• Mitochondrial genes have been used as molecular markers for species and strain identification, which can be applied to epidemiological studies and monitoring of microbes and parasites.

• The unique gene order rearrangements identified in some Schistosoma species provide valuable information for reconstructing the phylogenetic relationships of the parasite and other platyhelminthes.",0

625,"  <summary>

• Bacteriocins are ribosomally synthesized antimicrobial peptides produced by bacteria that have antimicrobial activity against a wide range of microorganisms, including Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.
• The classification of Gram-positive bacteriocins is difficult due to their heterogeneity, and the classification schemes have had to continuously evolve.

• Enterococcus faecalis strain S37 was isolated from poultry feces and was found to produce a bacteriocin with antimicrobial activity against various microorganisms, including Listeria and Campylobacter species.
• The antibacterial activity of enterocin S37 was assessed against a range of bacterial species, including Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.
• The cfs of E. faecalis S37 displayed activity against the target strains E. faecalis JH2-2, Lb. brevis F145, L. monocytogenes Egde, and L. innocua F, even after treatments with lipase and lysozyme.
• The antibacterial activity observed upon lipase and lysozyme treatments was similar to that observed with the untreated cfs.
• The cfs of E. faecalis S37 displayed a high degree of stability against heat, with no significant loss of antibacterial activity observed after heating at 80°C for 15 or 30 minutes.
• The cfs of E. faecalis S37 also displayed a high degree of stability against proteolytic enzymes, including chymotrypsin, papain, proteinase K, and lysozyme.
</summary>

* Bullet Point 1: Study Design and Methods

column2: + * Study Design: Phase 1, open-label, escalating-dose study
+ * Dose Cohorts: 6-10 participants per cohort (n = 28)
+ * Safety and Tolerability: Monitored for 29 days (1-mg and 3-mg cohorts) or 85 days (6-mg and 9-mg cohorts) post-dosing
+ * Lumbar Puncture: 3 lumbar punctures scheduled during the 2 trials for drug delivery and/or follow-up collection of cerebrospinal fluid
+ * Needle Size: 22- to 25-gauge spinal anesthesia needle (allowed if participant's weight or condition dictated)

+ * Institutional Guidelines: Eligible participants had to be able to complete all study procedures, meet age-appropriate institutional guidelines for lumbar puncture procedures, and have a life expectancy of > 2 years

+ * Exclusion Criteria: Serious respiratory insufficiency, hospitalization for surgery or pulmonary event within the past 2 months, active infection at screening, history of brain or spinal cord disease or bacterial meningitis, presence of implanted cerebrospinal fluid drainage shunt, clinically significant laboratory abnormalities, any ongoing medical condition that would interfere with the conduct and assessments of the study, or treatment with another investigational drug within 1 month of screening
+ * Patient Age: Medically stable spinal muscular atrophy participants 2 to 14 years of age were enrolled

+ * Study Sites: 4 sites in the United States (Boston Children's Hospital, Boston, MA; Columbia University Medical Center, New York, NY; Ut Southwestern Medical Center Children's Medical Center Dallas, Dallas, TX; and University of Utah School of Medicine, Salt Lake City, UT)

* Hydatid disease is a neglected zoonotic disease caused by Echinococcus granulosus parasite.

column2: + *Prevalence of human hydatidosis is high in many parts of the world, including Iran.
+ *In Iran, the disease is hyper-endemic in certain areas, particularly in rural and semi-rural regions.
+ *The parasite is transmitted through the bite of infected dogs, foxes, and jackals, and can also be spread through contaminated food and water.

column1: * Epidemiological and clinical aspects of hydatidosis in Iran:

column2: + *The majority of cases are found in the northeastern region of the country.
+ *The age group most affected is 21-40 years old.
+ *Women are more likely to be infected than men.
+ *The most common symptoms are abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and cough.
+ *Liver involvement is common, and multiple organ involvement is rare.
+ *Radiology and CT scan are the most common diagnostic methods.
+ *Risk factors for infection include contact with infected dogs, poor hygiene practices, and consuming contaminated food and water.
+ *Education programs are needed to improve recognition of the disease and identify infection sources in high-risk groups.

* Chfc (Ciliated Hepatic Foregut Cyst) is a rare congenital malformation of the liver.

column2: + *First described in 1857 by Friedrich, with only 103 cases reported worldwide since then.
+ *Most common location is segment IV of the left lobe, just beneath the hepatic capsule.
+ *Cyst size ranges from <1cm to 24cm in greatest diameter, with a median size of 3cm.
+ *Aspirate of hepatocytes admixed with ciliated cells and mucus cells can distinguish Chfc from other radiologically benign-appearing entities.
+ *Elevated Ca19-9 levels have been found in association with benign Chfc.

+ *Laparoscopic excision is the recommended treatment for Chfc larger than 4-5cm, symptomatic or enlarging lesions, and asymptomatic lesions with wall abnormalities on imaging or in patients with otherwise unexplained abnormal liver function tests.
+ *Minimally invasive approach is best suited for lesions in segments II to VI, the anterolateral portion of the liver, where visualization and access are easiest.

630,"  <summary>
• Orally dissolving strips are a promising alternative to traditional tablets and capsules.
• They offer several advantages, including ease of administration, faster dissolution, and improved patient compliance.
• • The development of orally dissolving strips has been driven by the need for faster and more convenient drug delivery systems.
• • These strips are designed to dissolve quickly and easily in the mouth, providing rapid absorption of the active ingredients.
• • The most common excipients used in orally dissolving strips are polymers, such as hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC) and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA).
• • These polymers provide the necessary mechanical strength and stability to the strips, while also allowing for rapid dissolution.
• • The formulation of orally dissolving strips involves the use of a solvent-casting method, where the drug is dissolved in a solvent and then cast onto a surface.
• • The solvent is then allowed to evaporate, leaving behind a thin layer of the drug.
• • The mechanical properties of orally dissolving strips, such as tensile strength and disintegration time, are critical to their performance.
• • These properties can be optimized through the use of different excipients and manufacturing processes.
• • In vitro dissolution testing is used to evaluate the performance of orally dissolving strips, by measuring the rate at which the drug dissolves in a controlled environment.
• • This testing can help identify any issues with the formulation and inform improvements to the strips.
</summary>",0

• Obesity is a global event linked to a sedentary lifestyle and a high-fat diet, which promotes chronic inflammation and metabolic disorders.
• A high-fat diet with or without ovariectomy increased the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines in rats, which may contribute to the development of cardiovascular disease.
• The loss of estrogen production during menopause leads to changes in the profile of lipoproteins, metabolism of glucose, and distribution of body fat, increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease.
• Estrogen has anti-inflammatory effects on the vasculature, and its deficiency during menopause may contribute to the development of atherosclerosis.
• The combination of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy increased the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines in adipose tissue, which may contribute to the development of metabolic disorders.
</summary>
• • Obesity and menopause are associated with chronic inflammation and metabolic disorders.
• • A high-fat diet with or without ovariectomy increased the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines in rats.

• • The loss of estrogen production during menopause leads to changes in the profile of lipoproteins, metabolism of glucose, and distribution of body fat, increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease.
• • Estrogen has anti-inflammatory effects on the vasculature, and its deficiency during menopause may contribute to the development of atherosclerosis.
• • The combination of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy increased the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines in adipose tissue.",0
634,"  • Bronchial artery embolization is a treatment for massive or life-threatening hemoptysis.
• The study analyzed 344 patients who underwent bronchial artery embolization for hemoptysis.
• The findings of angiography suggested that few direct signs were found during arteriography, and most indirect appearances supported a site of bleeding.
• The responsible arteries for different diseases were analyzed, and the main responsible arteries were right bronchial artery, left bronchial artery, and combined right and left bronchial trunk.
• Recurrent hemoptysis occurred in 61 patients within 1 month after undergoing embolization, and 74 patients had recurrent hemoptysis over 1 month after embolization.",0
635,"  •• Gastritis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the stomach lining.

•• Gastritis can be caused by a variety of factors, including infection with Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori), inflammatory diseases such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, and autoimmune disorders such as autoimmune gastritis.
•• H. pylori infection is a major cause of gastritis, and it is estimated that up to 70% of the world's population is infected with this bacterium.
•• H. pylori infection can lead to the development of chronic gastritis, which can progress to more severe conditions such as atrophic gastritis and gastric ulcers.
•• Autoimmune gastritis is a rare condition that occurs when the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the cells in the stomach lining, leading to inflammation and damage.
•• The exact cause of autoimmune gastritis is not known, but it is thought to be triggered by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

•• Treatment for gastritis depends on the underlying cause of the condition. For H. pylori infection, antibiotics are usually prescribed to eradicate the bacteria. For autoimmune gastritis, treatment may involve medications to suppress the immune system and reduce inflammation.
•• In some cases, surgery may be necessary to remove the damaged portion of the stomach.
•• It is important to seek medical attention if symptoms of gastritis persist or worsen over time, as untreated gastritis can lead to more serious complications such as stomach ulcers and bleeding.
•• Early diagnosis and treatment can help to prevent these complications and improve quality of life for individuals with gastritis.",0
636,"  <summary>
• • Inhibition of angiogenesis is required for tumor growth, and vegf is a primary stimulant of angiogenesis.
• • Anti-vegf therapy with bevacizumab, 2c3, or r84 reduces tumor size, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in an orthotopic breast cancer model.
• • Inhibition of vegf binding to vegfr2 is sufficient for effective blockade of the protumorigenic activity of vegf in breast cancer xenografts.

• • Reducing macrophage infiltration is an important aspect of anti-vegf therapy, and vegf is a major chemoattractant for inflammatory cells, including macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, myeloid-derived suppressor cells, and T cells.",0
637,"  • Vulvo-vaginal atrophy (VVA) is a common medical condition in postmenopausal women, affecting up to 32 million women in the US.

• VVA symptoms include dyspareunia (pain during sexual intercourse), vaginal dryness, and vaginal irritation, and can have a significant impact on a woman's quality of life, including her sexual relationships and overall well-being.
• The Revive survey, conducted among 15,576 postmenopausal women in the US, found that many women are unaware of the causes of VVA and the available treatment options.

• Only 35% of women who are using some form of treatment for VVA are satisfied with their current treatment, and many women are concerned about the safety and side effects of vaginal estrogen therapies.

• The survey also found that many women are not discussing their VVA symptoms with their healthcare providers, and that there is a lack of communication and understanding between women and their healthcare providers regarding VVA and its treatment options.",0

639,"  • Pad (peripheral arterial disease) is a common condition that affects the lower extremities, caused by atherosclerosis.
• Lipid peroxidation is a key mechanism by which several risk factors contribute to the development of pad.
• Simvastatin therapy has been shown to reduce lipid peroxidation and improve symptoms in patients with pad.
• • Indentation level 1:
• Pad is a common condition that affects the lower extremities, causing intermittent claudication and other symptoms.
• Lipid peroxidation is a key mechanism by which several risk factors contribute to the development of pad, including oxidized LDL.
• Simvastatin therapy has been shown to reduce lipid peroxidation and improve symptoms in patients with pad.
• • Indentation level 2:
• The study found that patients with pad had elevated levels of mda (malondialdehyde) and decreased levels of frap (ferric reducing antioxidant power) compared to healthy individuals.
• Simvastatin therapy reduced mda levels and increased frap levels in patients with pad, suggesting a reduction in lipid peroxidation.
• The study also found that ceruloplasmin activity was influenced by both simvastatin therapy and surgical treatment, but only 710 days postoperatively.
• The results suggest that simvastatin may have antioxidant properties that contribute to its efficacy in reducing lipid peroxidation and improving symptoms in patients with pad.",0
640,"  <summary>
*Fijk herbal mixture has been widely used in Nigeria for various ailments, but there is limited scientific data on its safety and efficacy.
*The study aimed to determine the effect of oral and repeated exposure to fijk on rat biochemical and morphological parameters.
*Levels of rat plasma total protein, alanine aminotransferase, alkaline phosphatase, and lipid profile were determined.
*Oral administration of fijk to rats did not produce significant change to average body weights, but significant reduction in rat plasma protein level was observed at double and triple doses.

*The determination of lipid profile showed that oral exposure of rats to fijk did not produce significant change in plasma level of total cholesterol, but significant elevation in rat plasma level of tryglyceride was observed at the highest dose.
</summary>
* *Effects on rat biochemical parameters:

column2: + Rat plasma total protein level was reduced significantly at double and triple doses of fijk.
+ Alanine aminotransferase level was elevated significantly in the group that received the highest dose of fijk.
+ Alkaline phosphatase level was reduced significantly in the group that received the highest dose of fijk.

column1: * *Effects on rat morphological parameters:

column2: + Rat liver weights were reduced in the treatment groups.
+ Liver morphology showed lesions such as hypochromia, hemorrhage, and ruptured vascular channels.
+ Rat plasma level of malondialdehyde (MDA) was elevated, indicating lipid peroxidation.",0

column1: 641,"  <summary>
* Carrier screening for autosomal recessive disorders before pregnancy can benefit prospective parents by identifying carriers and informing reproductive decisions.

* Current offer of preconceptional carrier tests through online providers includes individual tests for cystic fibrosis and panels of disorders for Ashkenazi Jews, but these tests are not widely available or recommended for the general population.
* Concerns about direct-to-consumer (DTC) genetic testing include the validity and utility of the tests, lack of medical supervision, and potential burden on public health resources.
* Preconceptional carrier screening has been accepted by medical associations, but DTC testing for these tests may be viewed differently due to lack of clinical utility and analytical validity.
* Important criteria for screening programs include the condition being an important health problem, suitable test with known predictive value, and favorable ratio of advantages to disadvantages.
</summary>

column2: + Benefits for prospective parents
+ Availability of individual tests and panels
+ Need for medical supervision and follow-up
+ Appropriate use of existing resources

column2: + Concerns about validity and utility
+ Lack of medical supervision
+ Potential burden on public health resources
+ Views on DTC testing for preconceptional carrier screening",0

column1: 643,"  • Glaucoma is a neurodegenerative disease involving gradual loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and optic nerve atrophy.
• Mller cells, the major type of glial cells in the retina, play an important role in retinal function and are involved in multiple pathological retinal diseases, including glaucoma.
• • Mller cells support and nourish retinal neurons, maintain extracellular ion homeostasis, glutamate recycling, and inflammation.
• • Mller cells are involved in the neurodegeneration in glaucoma through releasing cytokines such as TNF- and contributing to the neuroinflammation.
• • TNF- is a well-known pro-inflammatory cytokine that can aggravate retinal damage by releasing cytokines such as TNF- and necrosis factors, leading to apoptosis and necrosis.
• • AAA, a well-known compound that induces specific glial toxicity, can inhibit the glial toxicity of Mller cells and protect against retinal abnormalities in glaucoma.",0
644,"  <summary>
* Nonampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms (sdns) are challenging to treat due to their location and the risk of severe adverse events (SAEs) including delayed perforation.
* A new technique, laparoscopy-assisted endoscopic full-thickness resection with ligation device (LAEFTR-L), has been developed to address these challenges.
**Key advantages of LAEFTR-L:**
* Complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells
* Shorter operative time compared to conventional full-thickness resection (FTR) methods
**Tumor size and location considerations:**
* Lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter may be candidates for LAEFTR-L
* Mobilization of the portion close to the ampulla of vater is technically difficult with laparoscopic procedures, and LAEFTR-L cannot be applied to these areas.",0
645,"  <summary>
• • Cah is a group of autosomal recessive conditions caused by defects in cortisol synthesis.
• • Epidemiology, genetics, pathophysiology, clinical features, and management of cah will be reviewed.
• • Cah is caused by mutations in the cytochrome P450 21-hydroxylase gene (CYP21A2) located on chromosome 6p21.3.
• • The gene codes for the active 21-hydroxylase enzyme, and more than 90% of mutations are generated by recombinations between the active and inactive pseudogene.

• • The pathophysiology of cah is closely linked to the degree of enzyme deficiency, and the biosynthesis of cortisol is regulated by negative feedback on hypothalamic corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and pituitary adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion.

• • A defect in cortisol biosynthesis leads to a compensatory increase in hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH, which stimulates the adrenal cortex and results in the pathological correlative of hyperplastic adrenal glands.
• • Cah is classified as classic, severe form, or non-classic, mild or late-onset form, and classic cah is subclassified as salt-losing or non-salt-losing form.
• • Non-classic cah may be asymptomatic or associated with signs of androgen excess developing during childhood or at puberty.

• • Classic forms are characterized by congenital decrease of cortisol and aldosterone secretion and increase in androgen biosynthesis, and all female infants with classic cah typically have ambiguous genitalia at birth.

• • Boys with classic cah do not have signs of cah at birth, except for subtle hyperpigmentation and possible penile enlargement, and the age at diagnosis varies according to the severity of aldosterone deficiency.",0

648,"  <summary>
* Ventriculomegaly is a common finding in fetal imaging, with a prevalence of 0.3-1.5%.
* MRI is a valuable tool for evaluating ventriculomegaly, with higher sensitivity and specificity than ultrasound.
* MRI can detect additional anomalies in 50-70% of cases with ventriculomegaly, including cortical malformations, hydrocephalus, and intraventricular hemorrhage.
* The level of subspecialty training of the interpreting radiologist significantly improves the interobserver agreement for MRI interpretations.
* MRI is particularly useful for detecting small foci of brain hemorrhage or callosal anomalies in fetuses with cerebral ventriculomegaly.
* In the second trimester, MRI is useful for detecting white matter pathology and fossa posterior anomalies.
* Referring prenatal cases of ventriculomegaly for MRI is a topic of debate due to questions related to the diagnostic accuracy of MRI and practical issues.
* MRI is a sensitive technique for detecting small deposits of intraventricular blood, which may suggest an intraventricular hemorrhage as the cause of hydrocephaly.
* MRI is equally good for a morphometric and volumetric assessment of the fossa posterior in case of suspicious ultrasound findings.
* The excellent tissue contrast of MRI and the absence of bony interference make this technique ideal for cortical evaluation.
</summary>

\begin{tab}Indentation\end{tab}
\begin{tab}* MRI has higher sensitivity and specificity than ultrasound\end{tab}

column2: + *Management of hypertension and proteinuria

column3: + *Low dose of local anesthetic with intrathecal opioid is recommended

column1: 655,"  <summary>
* Milk yield depends on persistency of lactation, which is influenced by factors such as breed, parity, and age.

* The lactation curve is composed of ascending and descending slopes, with the ascending slope representing the rate of increase in milk yield before peak production, and the descending slope representing the rate of decrease in milk yield after peak production.
* Factors that affect the lactation curve include:

column2: + Parity: The first parity tends to have a lower initial milk yield and a longer time to reach peak yield compared to subsequent parities.

+ Breed: Different breeds have different lactation curves, with some breeds having a faster rate of increase in milk yield before peak production and a steeper decline in milk yield after peak production.
+ Age: Older cows tend to have a slower rate of increase in milk yield before peak production and a shallower decline in milk yield after peak production.
+ Nutrition and management: Proper nutrition and management can influence the shape of the lactation curve, with better nutrition and management leading to a more favorable lactation curve.

column1: </summary>",0

* *Disease Biomarkers*

column2: + *Diagnostic*: Detection of genetic variations associated with disease, such as SNPs, STRs, deletions, and insertions.
+ *Prognostic*: Measurement of biomarkers that predict the progression of a disease, such as tumor size or cancer-specific survival.
+ *Predictive*: Use of biomarkers to predict the response to a specific treatment, such as drug efficacy or toxicity.

column1: * *General Biomarkers*

column2: + *Discrete*: Biomarkers that are measured as a binary value (e.g., present or absent).
+ *Continuous*: Biomarkers that can take on any value within a continuous range.
+ *Stability*: Biomarkers that remain stable over time and across different samples.",0

column1: 658,"  <summary>
• Myosin Va (Myova) is a processive molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along actin filaments.
• Myova's directed motion is achieved through conformational changes in the motor domain following ATP hydrolysis, which is regulated by calmodulin.
• Myova's flexibility is crucial for its processivity, and:
• • Myova's subdomains have distinct flexural stiffness, which can be measured using tethered particle microscopy (TPM).
• • Calmodulin dissociation from the myova lever arm reduces the lever arm's flexural stiffness, contributing to the motor's compromised processivity in high calcium conditions.
• Myova constructs were expressed in the baculovirus / SF9 cell system and purified for TPM experiments.
• Double-headed myova constructs were coexpressed with calcium-insensitive calmodulin to study the effect of calmodulin dissociation on myova's processivity.
• Qdots were attached to myova constructs to measure their flexural stiffness using TPM.

• The myova constructs' flexural stiffness was found to be dependent on their structural domains, and calmodulin dissociation reduced the lever arm's flexural stiffness, contributing to the motor's compromised processivity in high calcium conditions.",0

column1: 660,"  <summary>
• • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, with a prevalence of 50-70%.
• • The most common clinical forms of OPC are pseudomembranous (52.6%), erythematous (13.15%), angular cheilitis (13.15%), and a combination of acute candidosis and erythema (10.52%).
• • Candida species isolated from oral cavity in 76% of patients, with C. albicans being the most frequent (92%), followed by C. tropicalis (5.26%) and C. glabrata (2.64%).

• • The distribution of OPC lesions based on CD4+ count showed that 62% of lesions occurred in patients with CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm, 26% in patients with CD4+ count of 201-499 cells/mm, and 12% in patients with CD4+ count > 500 cells/mm.
</summary>
• • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, with a prevalence of 50-70%.
• • Pseudomembranous candidiasis is the most common clinical form of OPC, accounting for 52.6% of cases.
• • The distribution of OPC lesions based on CD4+ count showed a correlation between the severity of immunodeficiency and the prevalence of OPC.
• • Candida species isolated from oral cavity in 76% of patients, with C. albicans being the most frequent, followed by C. tropicalis and C. glabrata.",0
661,"  <summary>Magnetic Tracers for Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy</summary>
• Magnetic tracers are used for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) to identify and remove the sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) that are the first to drain from a tumor.
• Three different magnetic tracers were used in this study: Feraheme / Rienso, Sienna+, and Endorem / Feridex.
• • Hydrodynamic particle size of the tracers was determined using dynamic light scattering.
• • Iron content of the tracers was quantified using vibrating sample magnetometry.
• • The tracers were diluted to the same iron concentration of 11.2 mg Fe/mL for comparison of performance.
• • The study used a porcine model that closely resembles human lymphatic drainage to evaluate the performance of the magnetic tracers.
• • Six mini-pigs were injected with each of the three tracers subcutaneously in the areolas of the third inguinal mammary glands.
• • Transcutaneous magnetometer measurements were performed in the inguinal region at different time points after tracer injection.
• • Sites of uptake of the magnetic tracers were marked using a permanent marker.
• • Removed lymph nodes were fixed in formalin and sent for iron quantification and histopathological evaluation.
• • The study aimed to compare the performance of the three magnetic tracers for SLNB.",0

column1: 663,"  <summary>
• • Summary of the main findings:

column2: • • • The study examined the use of rhegf as a treatment for diabetic foot ulcers.
• • • The study found that rhegf treatment resulted in significant improvements in ulcer healing, as measured by the area of the ulcer and the percentage of granulation tissue covering the wound.

• • • The study also found that the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC) for the surrogate markers of complete healing (percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and eot) was maximized when using the granulation tissue variable.
• • • The study used a placebo-controlled trial design and found that the product coefficient (pc) was 0.67, indicating a significant mediating effect of granulation tissue on ulcer closure.
• • • The study also found that the proportion mediated was 0.75, indicating that 75% of the effect of treatment on ulcer closure was mediated by granulation tissue.

* Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in older adults.
* Up to 30% of patients with neovascular AMD do not respond to anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) therapy, and these patients are considered treatment-resistant.
* The management of treatment-resistant neovascular AMD involves the use of continuing anti-VEGF treatment to control signs of exudation and prevent vision loss.

* Aflibercept, a fusion protein of key domains from human VEGF receptors 1 and 2 with the constant region of human immunoglobulin G, has been shown to be effective in improving visual acuity and reducing the risk of vision loss in patients with treatment-resistant neovascular AMD.
</summary>

+ * Early detection and treatment of neovascular AMD can help prevent vision loss.

• Endometrial cancer is the most common invasive malignancy of the female genital tract, and early screening methods have made significant progress due to improvements in cytological preparation methods and unified evaluation systems.

• The study aimed to investigate the adequacy of specimens obtained using the Sap-1 device for endometrial cytology testing and compare it with those obtained via dilation and curettage (D&C) or hysteroscopic biopsy.
• The study included 1514 patients with endometrial cancer risk factors who underwent Sap-1 sampling, and 375 of them also underwent D&C or hysteroscopy.
• The majority of patients were over 40 years of age in both the cytology and histopathology groups (91.2% and 90.7%, respectively).
• The percentage of postmenopausal women was 69% and 63.5% in the two groups, respectively.
• Among 1514 cases with cytology specimens, 576 (38%) patients had abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), and 910 (60.1%) had endometrial thickness of 4 mm or more measured by ultrasound.
• There were 169 (45.1%) inadequate cytology specimens and 90 (24%) inadequate biopsy specimens.
• Sap-1 can provide more sufficient materials for cytology than D&C or hysteroscopic biopsy (p < 0.01).
• The accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) of cytology for detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma were estimated.

• The study found that cytology and histology results were consistent in 254 patients, and 1006 (86.3%) of the 1200 cytology samples obtained using Sap-1 were adequate, while 37 (3.7%) were inadequate.
• The study concluded that Sap-1 sampling is a reliable method for",0

• Endothelial dysfunction is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, particularly in the elderly.
• Oxidative stress is a key mechanism underlying endothelial dysfunction, leading to reduced nitric oxide production and increased vascular inflammation.
• Nitric oxide (NO) is a critical regulator of vascular tone and inflammation, and its reduction contributes to the development of atherosclerosis.

• The endothelium produces NO through the catalytic activity of nitric oxide synthase (NOS), which requires five cofactors/prosthetic groups: flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), flavin mononucleotide (FMN), heme, tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), and calcium.
• Calcium is required for the activation of inducible NOS (iNOS) but not for the activity of endothelial NOS (eNOS), and the imbalance between these isoforms contributes to endothelial dysfunction.

• The endothelium also produces other vasoactive substances, such as prostacyclin and endothelium-derived hyperpolarizing factor (EDHF), which play a role in maintaining vascular tone and inflammation.
• The aging process is associated with a decline in endothelial function, including reduced NO production, increased vascular inflammation, and impaired endothelial repair mechanisms.
• Exercise training has been shown to improve endothelial function in older adults, possibly through the enhancement of antioxidant defenses and the promotion of nitric oxide production.
• Vitamin C supplementation has also been shown to improve endothelial function in older adults, possibly through the reduction of oxidative stress and the enhancement of nitric oxide production.
• The endothelium is a critical component of the cardiovascular system, and its dysfunction is a major contributor to the development of cardiovascular disease.
• The mechanisms underlying endothelial dysfunction are complex and involve the interplay of oxidative stress, inflammation, and",0

* Invasion biology and management have been the subject of much criticism over the past 25 years.

column2: + Critics argue that the field of invasion biology is overblown and that the problems caused by introduced species are overstated.
+ Some critics argue that the focus on invasive species is xenophobic and that the field is ignoring the impacts of native species on ecosystems.
+ Others argue that the field is too focused on eradication and management of invasive species, rather than addressing the root causes of invasions.
+ Some critics also argue that the field is too focused on individual species, rather than considering the broader ecological impacts of invasions.

column1: * Despite these criticisms, the importance of invasion biology and management cannot be ignored.

column2: + Invasive species can have significant impacts on ecosystems, including biodiversity loss, altered ecosystem processes, and economic losses.
+ The lag effect of invasions, where the full impacts of an introduced species are not felt for years or even decades, makes it difficult to manage invasions effectively.
+ The subtlety of some impacts of invasive species, where the impacts are not immediately apparent, makes it difficult to identify and manage invasions.
+ The complexity of invasions, where multiple factors contribute to the success of an introduced species, makes it difficult to develop effective management strategies.

• Indentation level 1
• Indentation level 2
• Researchers have been exploring the use of cuscn as a sensitized photocathode in dye-sensitized solar cells.
• Cuscn is a p-type, wide-bandgap semiconductor that has been frequently used as a hole conductor in nanostructured solar cells.
• The addition of dyes to the bath for electrodeposition of cuscn has been shown to improve the photocathodic properties of the material.
• The use of cuscn / rb hybrid thin films has been found to be a promising approach for improving the efficiency of dye-sensitized solar cells.
• The mechanism of cuscn electrodeposition was poorly understood at the time of the previous work, which made it difficult to achieve hybrid thin films with composition similar to that of zno / ey.
• The use of a rotating disc electrode (RDE) system has been found to be essential for obtaining cuscn thin films with perfect homogeneity and high reproducibility.
• The addition of rb to the bath has been shown to be a successful strategy for forming nanostructured cuscn and improving the photocathodic properties of the material.
• The amount of rb loaded into the film can be determined by measuring the absorption spectrum of the film in ammonia solution.
• The amount of electrodeposited cuscn can be determined by measuring the amount of cu in the ammonia solution dissolving the film according to the classical colorimetric analysis method.
• The Faradaic efficiency for the electrodeposition of cuscn can be calculated by comparing the amount of consumed charge with the amount of cu deposited.
• The loaded rb molecules can be extracted by soaking the film in dma, and the fraction of extractable rb can be determined by comparing the absorption spectra before and after the dma treatment.

680,"  • Nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut, and is a remnant of embryonic communication between the notochord and the roof of the pharynx.
• The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is less than 1% of all rhinitis patients seen during the study period.
• Two types of nasopharyngeal bursitis were identified: cystic and crust types.

• The cystic type presents with postnasal discharge, throat irritation, and cough, while the crust type presents with crust expectoration and retching, with or without fetid postnasal discharge, and occasional occipital pain.
• The crust type may be a distinct variant of the disease that may develop at any time, without recognized predisposing factors.

• Endoscopic examination of the nasopharynx after proper nasal decongestion will clearly show either a cyst or ulcer-like lesion covered with crusts in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx.
• Radiologic investigation (simple lateral view X-ray, computed tomography scan, and magnetic resonance imaging) is useful in showing adhesion of the bursa to the cervical vertebrae.",0

column2: + Preprocessing techniques are essential to remove artifacts and enhance image quality.
+ Color space transformation, color quantization, contrast enhancement, and artifact removal are common preprocessing techniques used in dermatoscopy image analysis.
+ Color quantization reduces the number of colors in the image to improve precision in quantization.
+ Histogram equalization and homomorphic filtering can be used to compensate for uneven illumination and specular reflection variations.

column1: * Hair removal is a significant challenge in dermatoscopy image analysis.

+ Morphological closing operators and uniform color space techniques can also be used to remove hairs.
+ However, these techniques may result in blurring and color bleeding, making it difficult to use the color diffuse image for further skin tumor differentiation.

* Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a chronic disease characterized by high blood glucose levels, which are caused by both insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency.

column2: + T2D is a major public health burden, with 366 million people affected worldwide in 2030, and this number is expected to rise to 552 million by 2050 if no action is taken.
+ The latest studies have shown that the esrra gene is a candidate gene involved in the pathogenesis of T2D.

+ The esrra gene is a nuclear orphan receptor belonging to the NR superfamily, group III, and it plays a crucial role in various cell functions, including mitochondrial biogenesis, mitochondrial oxidative metabolism, carbohydrate metabolism, adaptive energy metabolism, and lipid metabolism.
+ The mfn2 gene is a mitochondrial fusion protein that regulates mitochondrial morphology and distribution, and it is involved in the regulation of glucose metabolism and insulin signaling.
+ The mfn2 gene is associated with T2D, and the c allele of the rs2878677 variant is associated with a lower risk of T2D.
+ Haplotypes in the mfn2 gene are also associated with T2D, and the g-t-c-t-c haplotype is associated with an increased risk of T2D.

* Congenital toxoplasmosis is a protozoan infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that can lead to various neurological complications, including mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.
* This case report describes a 34-year-old Arabian female who presented with medically intractable seizures and was diagnosed with congenital toxoplasmosis.
* The patient had a history of hydrocephalus and right ventriculoperitoneal shunting at 1 month old, and complained of decreased visual acuity in both eyes.
* Neurological examination revealed contracture and a mental status of 22, suggesting memory impairment and inattention.
* Brain imaging studies revealed multifocal parenchymal calcifications, including a calcified nodule in the perihippocampal area, which were consistent with congenital toxoplasmosis.
* The patient had a history of psychic aura followed by generalized seizures with right eye deviation and head version.
* Video/electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring revealed 5 complex partial seizures (CPS) and 2 generalized tonic-clonic (GTC) seizures, all of which were started with psychic aura.

* The patient underwent ictal and interictal 99m-technetium (Tc) hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime single photon emission computed tomography (HMPAO-SPECT) and brain functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), which showed hypoperfusion in the left frontotemporal area and focal hypermetabolism in the left medial temporal cortex, respectively.

* The patient was referred to the epilepsy clinic for further evaluation and management of her seizures, and underwent surgical resection of the epileptogenic focus, including the calcified nodule in the perihippocampal area.

* This case highlights the association between congenital toxoplasmosis and mesial temporal lobe epilepsy, and the importance of comprehensive evaluation and surgical treatment for managing seizures in patients with congenital to",0
685,"  • Cost analysis of laparoscopic cholecystectomy
• Level 1:
• • Approximately 20 million people in the US have gallstones, and 1 million are diagnosed annually.
• • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most costly digestive disease, with an estimated annual cost of over $5 billion.
• • In 1992, the National Institute of Health convened a consensus development conference to discuss the treatment of cholelithiasis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

• • After reviewing current literature and considering the costs of open cholecystectomy, the panel concluded that laparoscopic cholecystectomy offers substantial advantages over open cholecystectomy with no apparent increase in morbidity or mortality.
• • The disability and loss of income following standard open cholecystectomy increase costs, but these items are generally not measured by traditional appraisal methods.
• • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy has a reduced length of stay (LOS) and short-term disability, which should result in lower hospital charges.
• • However, charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy often surpass those of open cholecystectomy.
• • Decision tree and sensitivity analyses can be used to determine the cost-effectiveness of laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
• • A $3,331 reduction in the charge of laparoscopic cholecystectomy would be needed to make it cost-effective for all patients.
• • The greater the amount of reduction needed, the less likely efficiency can be achieved by reducing laparoscopic cholecystectomy charges.",0

• Type 1 diabetes is characterized by progressive autoimmune destruction of pancreatic cells, leading to insulinopenia and variable degrees of hypoglycemia.
• The period of remission (PR) is defined as the interval between diagnosis and the onset of hypoglycemia, during which insulin secretion is restored.
• PR duration is an important factor in determining the long-term outcome of type 1 diabetes, with longer durations associated with better glycemic control and lower risk of complications.
• The study found that 56.2% of patients with type 1 diabetes experienced PR, with no case of complete remission.
• Girls and boys had similar frequencies of PR, and the duration of PR was not significantly different between age subgroups.
• At diagnosis, patients with PR had lower baseline a1c levels than those without PR, and this effect was more pronounced in girls.
• Multivariate logistic regression analysis showed that the chance of PR was higher when there was no DKA at diagnosis, and lower a1c levels at diagnosis were associated with higher chances of PR.
</summary>

688,"  • Chondroblastoma is a rare bone tumor that accounts for less than 1% of all primary bone tumors.
• It typically affects the epiphyseal regions of the tubular bones, especially the ends of the tibia, femur, and humerus.
• In the head and neck region, chondroblastoma occurs more frequently and can affect the temporal bone or the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).
• Malignant changes have been observed in chondroblastoma after irradiation, making it a contraindication for radiation therapy.
• Accurate diagnosis is crucial, as misdiagnosis can lead to unnecessary treatments and delays in appropriate treatment.
• The patient in this case study was initially misdiagnosed with giant cell tumor and underwent several unsuccessful treatments before being referred to the authors' department.
• Immunohistochemical examination of the lesion showed reactivity of the neoplastic protein mass for S-100 protein, which is a diagnostic criterion for chondroblastoma.
• Total en bloc excision is the preferred treatment for chondroblastoma in the temporal bone, but it can be challenging due to the location of important neurovascular components.
• Modified surgical procedures can be used for patients with later-stage chondroblastoma, as seen in this case study.",0

* *Metabolic interactions between microbes:

column2: + Complementation: Microbes can complement each other's growth by sharing metabolites.
+ Cross-feeding: Microbes can feed on each other's metabolic byproducts.
+ Mutualism: Microbes can form mutualistic relationships where both benefit from the interaction.
+ Antagonism: Microbes can form antagonistic relationships where one benefits and the other is harmed.

695,"  • Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome (BSS) is a rare genodermatosis caused by mutations in the cylindromatosis gene (Cyld) on chromosome 16q12q13.
• BSS is characterized by the progressive formation of adnexal skin tumors in the scalp and face, mainly trichoepiteliomas, cylindromas, and spiradenomas.
• The syndrome is due to germ-line mutations in the Cyld gene, which predispose to the disease, and sometimes, a second acquired somatic mutation determines the final phenotype.

• Around 93 different mutations have been identified in the Cyld gene, and the particularities of the clinical manifestations may support the hypothesis about the relationship between the germline mutation and the final phenotype.
• The authors present a new case of BSS in a family due to the heterozygous Cyld mutation c.1628_1629delct.

• The particularities of the clinical manifestations (late onset and relatively low number of tumors) may support the hypothesis about the relationship between the germline mutation and the final phenotype.
• The genetic study revealed the existence of the heterozygotic mutation c.1628_1629delct in three women of the same family.

• The authors certify that they have obtained all appropriate patient consent forms, and the patients understand that their names and initials will not be published, but anonymity cannot be guaranteed.",0

column1: 698,"  <summary>
• • Cardiovascular diseases, including hypertension and heart failure, are caused by the local production of aldosterone and the activation of its mineralocorticoid receptor (MR).
• • Aldosterone activates its MR in the non-diabetic heart and can cause structural and electrical remodeling, fibrosis, oxidative stress, inflammation, and arrhythmias.
• • MR antagonists have shown significant benefits in patients with left ventricular dysfunction and myocardial infarction.
• • However, beneficial effects of MR blockade in pathological states such as diabetes are unclear.
• • Inhibition of angiotensin II does not reliably suppress aldosterone production, with the aldosterone escape phenomenon occurring in up to 40% of patients with heart failure.
• • The need for additional RAAS inhibition in these individuals would be a logical consequence, and combinations of ACEi or ARBs with MR antagonists may offer added benefits.

• • The aim of the present study was to characterize and compare the effects of RU28318 (RU), captopril (CAP), losartan (LOS), RU + CAP, RU + LOS, CAP + LOS, and RU + CAP + LOS (triple therapy) on cardiac function in isolated hearts from normal and diabetic rats.

• • The study found that RU resulted in the most rapid recovery in cardiac function parameters, including +dp/dt, dp/dt, and cf, within the first 10 minutes of reperfusion in both normal and diabetic hearts.

• • Interestingly, cap + los therapy given before ischemia resulted in a very rapid improvement in pmax and cf within the first 10 minutes of reperfusion in diabetic hearts, which was almost the maximal recovery obtained.

• • Ru + los yielded the most rapid recovery in lvedp when given before ischemia in nondiabetic hearts, and capt + los therapy given before ischemia resulted in a very rapid improvement in pmax within the first 10 minutes of reperfusion in diabetic hearts.",0
699,"  <summary>
* Modern nasal surgery aims to improve both the cosmetic appearance and natural function of the nose.
* Acoustic rhinometry is a reliable and objective method for measuring nasal dimensions before and after surgery.
* In this study, we evaluated the changes in nasal dimensions of healthy Iranian volunteers after rhinoplasty using acoustic rhinometry.
* The results showed that the cross-sectional area of the nasal airway, minimal cross-sectional area (MCa), and volume of each nasal cavity decreased significantly after surgery.
* However, the reduction in MCa1 was significant only in the group without decongestant, while the reduction in MCa2 was significant in both groups with and without decongestant.
* Placing a columellar strut in the group of rhinoplasty plus septoplasty caused a significant increase in MCa1 and a decrease in MCa2.
* Osteotomy, especially double osteotomy, positively affects nose function by increasing MCa1 and reducing constriction in MCa2.
* The findings of this study suggest that performing septoplasty or osteotomy may be beneficial for patients with mildly deviated septum or nasal obstruction.
</summary>
Level 1:
* *Measuring nasal dimensions before and after surgery is important for evaluating the effectiveness of rhinoplasty.
* *Acoustic rhinometry is a reliable and objective method for measuring nasal dimensions.
* *The cross-sectional area of the nasal airway, minimal cross-sectional area (MCa), and volume of each nasal cavity are important parameters for evaluating nasal function.
* *The reduction in MCa1 and MCa2 after surgery indicates improved nasal patency.
Level 2:
* *Placing a columellar strut in the group of rhinoplasty plus septoplasty caused a significant increase in MCa1 and a decrease in MCa2.
* *Double osteotomy positively affects nose function by increasing MCa1 and reducing constriction in MCa2.
* *Performing septoplasty or oste",0
700,"  • Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in many developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths.

• Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance.
• N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) were proved to have anti-inflammatory effects, and their lipid-lowering action was detected at the beginning of the research.
• Low-grade chronic inflammation is now recognized as a prominent process in the development of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease.
• The induction of inflammation may provide a link between hyperlipidemia and atherogenesis.
• Atherosclerosis is a systemic disease characterized by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions that can develop through the disease progression.
• Unsaturated fatty acids are referred to as PUFAs when two or more double bonds are present.
• The human body can produce almost all fatty acids, except linoleic acid (LA), which is a precursor to the n-6 series of fatty acids.
• Results from pilot studies suggest that LA conversion is also limited to function as a surrogate for fish consumption.
• There is a vast amount of epidemiologic evidence of a cardioprotective effect of fish oil-derived EPA and DHA, and it was confirmed in randomized controlled trials.",0
701,"  <summary>
• Gastric cancer is a major public health burden worldwide, with a high mortality rate.
• The three pathologists who made significant contributions to understanding the etiology of gastric cancer are Rudolf Virchow, Pelayo Correa, and Robin Warren.
• Virchow, a 19th-century Prussian physician-scientist, hypothesized that cancer arose from normal cells in response to chronic inflammation.
• Correa, a Colombian pathologist, devoted his professional career to understanding the etiology of gastric cancer, particularly the role of Helicobacter pylori.
• Warren, an Australian pathologist, discovered the role of H. pylori in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.
• The initial evidence for a link between H. pylori and gastric cancer was weak, but later cohort studies provided convincing evidence.
• H. pylori infection increases the risk of gastric cancer, regardless of the histologic subtype.
• Measuring H. pylori exposure by ELISA underestimates prior exposure, leading to false-negative results.
• Eradication of H. pylori can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer.
</summary>

703,"  <summary>
* Mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) and severe hypoproteinemia (SHP) are two types of proteinuria in preeclampsia (PE)

column2: + *MHP: proteinuria < 300 mg/24 h, urinary protein-to-creatinine ratio < 0.3
+ *SHP: proteinuria < 300 mg/24 h, urinary protein-to-creatinine ratio < 0.3, or a urine dipstick protein grade of 1+ or greater
+ Exclusion criteria: kidney diseases, preexisting proteinuria, essential hypertension, or other maternal chronic conditions
+ Maternal outcomes: delivery mode, eclampsia, hellp syndrome, hypertension, abnormal liver function, abnormal renal function, ascites, oligohydramnios, thrombocytopenia, and abruptio placenta
+ Neonatal outcomes: perinatal deaths, preterm birth, neonatal asphyxia, and fetal growth restriction
+ SHP was associated with a higher risk of cesarean section, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes
+ The pathophysiologic mechanisms of PE are unclear, but scholars believe that defects in placental implantation and function lead to the development of PE
+ PE patients often complicated with multiple organ hypoperfusion, which can lead to the gradual development of hypoproteinemia
+ The mortality associated with PE and eclampsia was about 0.83 per 100,000 maternities
+ PE is also strongly related with intrauterine growth restriction, neonatal asphyxia, low birth weight, preterm delivery, and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
+ A common robust biomarker has not been detected, but this study evaluated maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE according to the different value of albumin.

column1: 704,"  • Targeting Vegf Signaling in Cancer

1. The vegf signaling pathway has been extensively studied in cancer, and various agents have been developed to target this pathway, including mAbs, ptk inhibitors, and small molecule inhibitors of vegf receptors.
2. The use of mAbs, such as bevacizumab (Avastin), has been shown to be effective in treating various types of cancer, including colorectal, lung, and renal cell carcinoma.

3. However, the recent withdrawal of bevacizumab for treating breast cancer in the United States highlights the limitations of anti-angiogenic treatments and the need for careful cost-benefit analyses in cancer treatment.

4. The vegf family members, including vegf-a, vegf-c, vegf-d, pigf, vegfr-1, vegfr-2, and vegfr-3, have been shown to play a role in cancer, and targeting these growth factors may provide a potential approach for improving cancer treatment.
5. Future studies should focus on identifying specific cancer indications for which these agents are most effective and developing strategies to overcome resistance to anti-angiogenic drugs.",0
705,"  <summary>Malaria Diagnostic Techniques in Iran</summary>
• Malaria is still a significant public health concern in Iran, particularly in the southeastern regions.
• Asymptomatic malaria infections are a major challenge in malaria control and elimination, and early detection is crucial.
• Level 1:
• • Microscopic examination is the standard method for malaria diagnosis, but it has limitations, such as low sensitivity and specificity.
• • Rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) are widely used in remote areas where microscopy is impractical or unfeasible.
• • Molecular diagnostic techniques, such as nested-PCR, are highly sensitive and can detect low parasitemia levels.
• Level 2:
• • Nested-PCR is a highly sensitive method for detecting Plasmodium species, particularly P. vivax and P. falciparum.
• • The study found a high concordance between the outcomes of routine malaria diagnostic techniques and nested-PCR in detecting asymptomatic cases.
• • The results of this investigation can help inform malaria elimination strategies in Iran and other endemic regions.",0

column1: 707,"  <summary>
• Bone density and architecture are intimately dependent on mechanical factors.
• Piezoelectric materials and converse piezoelectric effect can produce effective osteoblast mechanical stimulation.
• Micro-movements at the interface may enhance osteogenesis or impair it and promote the formation of fibrous tissue.
• Actuator device was implanted in the left hind limb and a control device was implanted in the right hind limb of a 4-year-old merino ewe.
• Total bone area around the actuators was significantly higher than in static controls, indicating new bone formation.
• Mineral apposition rate was significantly higher around actuated devices than around static devices, indicating enhanced bone growth.
• Immunohistochemistry failed to detect differences in trap expression between the two groups, but there is a marked elevation in opn detection around actuators.
• Opn is strongly labeled in the fibroblast layers closer to the PVDF films, and positive pcna labeling was found more often in these areas.
• Micro-movements at the interface may enhance osteogenesis or impair it and promote the formation of fibrous tissue.

• The chosen staining technique, giemsa eosin, stains older bone in a darker shade of pink, while more recently deposited bone is of a lighter pink color and frequently adjacent to much less prominent osteoid (dark blue) areas.
• The significant differences arise from the bone areas surrounding the two distal thirds of the devices.
</summary>",0
708,"  <summary>
• • Summary of the study on serum L-fucose levels in oral cancer patients
• • Level 1
• • 1. The study was conducted on 90 individuals, including 60 oral cancer patients and 30 healthy controls.
• • 2. The serum L-fucose level was estimated using clinical chemistry autoanalyzer based on the Winzler method.
• • 3. The study revealed a significant difference in the mean serum L-fucose levels between the cancer and control groups (7.38 mg/dL).
• • 4. The serum L-fucose level progressively increased with the stage of cancer, showing a maximum value of 12.54 mg/dL in stage IV.
• • 5. The study found a negative correlation between serum L-fucose levels and histopathological tumor differentiation.
• • 6. The serum L-fucose level remained constant among healthy individuals and was raised proportionately in oral cancer patients, commensurate with the stage of cancer.

• • 7. The study suggests that serum L-fucose levels can be used as an easy, non-invasive, cost-effective, biochemical indicator of cancer detection, staging, therapeutic success, prognosis, and as a post-treatment evaluation tool.
• • 8. Further investigation on a large scale would likely prove serum L-fucose as an effective tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of oral cancer.
</summary>",0
